PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF MIRAGE AIRCRAFT TO PAKISTAN

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the statement by the official spokesman of the Ministry of External Affairs, Government of India, dated 19 October 1990, which states in part:

QUESTION.PARA: Government of India expresses its dismay and unhappiness with the decision of the Government of Australia to ship 50 Mirage-III aircraft shortly to Pakistan . . .

Contrary to assurances given by Foreign Minister of Australia during his talks with External Affairs Minister in New Delhi in August 1990, the Australian Government has unfortunately chosen to ignore the realities of the situation in the region and gone ahead with the deal . . . We had least expected that a friendly Australia would take action which has the effect of further disturbing stability of the region.

I ask the Minister: Is this the statement of the Indian foreign ministry which the Minister says was fundamentally wrong? Are those in India who have indicated that bilateral ministerial talks have now been cancelled also fundamentally wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the statement I was referring to. The suggestion that Australia had acted contrary to assurances given was fundamentally and absolutely wrong and justified the terms of my reaction to it. It was the subject of a press release I put out at the time-I do not have a copy of that with me. I do have with me, however, a copy of something which I meant to table the other day in light of Senator Teague's question about what I had said in Pakistan on the subject. I have a bit of paper which has the relevant extracts of my public press conferences, both in New Delhi on Thursday, 2 August and in Islamabad on Sunday, 5 August, which goes to the question of the delivery dates and what I actually said, which is the assurance that allegedly was given and has now been broken. I gave no such assurance. What I said on the public record makes that perfectly clear. I was hardly likely to say on the public record something different from what I was saying privately, for very obvious reasons. I seek leave to incorporate those two extracts in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Extract of press conference at Shastri Bhavan, New Delhi on Thursday 2 August 1990:
Question from Ashok Sharma (PTI): What is the time framework with Pakistan for the actual delivery of the aircraft?

Senator Evans: The contract spoke in terms of delivery within six months of the date of agreement, i.e. by mid-October, subject to mutually agreed shipping arrangements being worked out. In practice there has been some slippage in the working out of those shipping arrangements and my present understanding is that the actual delivery of the crated up aircraft will be somewhat further delayed. The fact that there has been that delay is, I think, proof in itself of the fact that these are not regarded as exactly super top priority military acquisitions by Pakistan. What we are talking about here is appearances rather than substance, but appearances in diplomacy and politics can be very important, as we all know.
Extract of press conference with Pakistani press, Islamabad, Sunday 5 August 1990:
Question from Reuters Journalist: Are there still any difficulties with this Mirage deal, or is it finally settled and when will the delivery take place?

Senator Evans: . . . In terms of the actual delivery schedule, it was the terms of the contract that those deliveries occur within six months of the final agreement being entered into in April this year. That delivery schedule, I think, has slipped a bit, through no fault of anyone and no deliberate decision by anyone. It may be that deliveries will not occur now until the early part of next year, but that remains to be seen and the general principles that will govern this matter are as I have just described.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the question of the alleged cancellation of a ministerial meeting, there has been no cancellation of a meeting because no such meeting was ever scheduled. In the context of an anticipated meeting of Commonwealth Foreign Ministers in New Delhi early in December, there was some initial exploratory discussion of the possibility of bringing forward a joint ministerial meeting at that time. But there were difficulties about dates that had simply not been bedded down in any way. There was continuing uncertainty as to the dates of the Foreign Ministers meeting on southern Africa. In fact, in the last 48 hours, that meeting has now been deferred. It will not take place until early next year. The press report this morning on that subject was as big a beat up as most of the reports on this whole issue have been throughout.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to an investigation into the airline crash in Britain last year when a Boeing 737-400 crashed across a motorway. The main recommendations coming from that investigation included a recommendation that the floors of aircraft be strengthened and that passenger seats be faced backwards, rather than forwards, for safety. Given that one Australian domestic airline has just purchased some of this type of aircraft, can the Minister indicate whether these recommendations will be looked at by aviation authorities in Australia?

—The answer to Senator Maguire's question is yes, they will. I should point out to Senator Maguire that, for the purposes of pilot endorsement, the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has identified this aircraft type as being distinctly different from the earlier models of 737-200s and 300s that operate in Australia. The report of the British authorities into this disaster in Great Britain has only just been completed. The CAA is not yet in possession of the report of that incident, but it will be getting it and it will pay due regard to the recommendations of the report.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Government made a submission to the Remuneration Tribunal to increase the salaries of senior members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission by 6 per cent from 1 January? If so, what is the basis of the Government's decision? Will it lead to a national wage claim of 6 per cent by all salary and wage earners, as threatened by Mr Kelty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, or more accurately I, as representative of the Government, early last week referred a matter to the Remuneration Tribunal for determination. I did so routinely, before it became known what the September quarter consumer price index (CPI) figure would be. There was a return of 0.7 per cent for the September quarter CPI figure, the September quarter being the critical quarter as far as the accord is concerned. The first wage increase under accord mark 6 applies as the percentage that comes out of the September quarter figure. I referred the matter to the Tribunal before the September quarter figure was known.

ANSWER.PARA: That September quarter figure is quite a significant result for the Government. As a consequence of that result for the Government, we have an unrivalled opportunity to break the cycle of inflation and to put Australia in a better competitive position with our trading partners. The only way in which we can do that is by operating with and through the accord. I am now looking closely at the effect that September quarter return will have on the accord and wages policy generally. Because I am, I will include in that examination the matter we have referred to the Remuneration Tribunal concerning the Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked specifically whether the submission had recommended an increase of 6 per cent as from 1 January for senior members of the Tribunal. Is the Minister saying that it did but he will now review it? If he is not saying that, what is he saying?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I made it fairly clear. I said that last week I referred the matter. Senator Durack in his question referred to 6 per cent; the proposition we referred to the Remuneration Tribunal was for 6 per cent. In the normal course of events, one would expect the Remuneration Tribunal to receive our notification and then, in the appropriate way and the appropriate form, deal with it. What I am saying in answer to Senator Durack's question is that yes, we referred it, but that was before the September quarter CPI figure came out. The September quarter CPI was 0.7 per cent. Most of the pundits predicted 1.5 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: As a consequence of that return, we now have an unrivalled opportunity in this country. We would be foolish in the extreme if, not using the strength of the accord and the relationship created by it, we did not look at overall wages policy and overall opportunities created to break out of the cycle of inflation. As a consequence, we will do that. We will include in that examination, as we would include all wages and salaries in that examination, the question of the reference that Senator Durack asked me about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Firstly, following the success of Anne Fairbairn in gaining the release of two Australian hostages, and in light of the Iraqi Ambassador's undertaking that all Australian hostages would be released if Australian ships were withdrawn from the Gulf, is the Government continuing with its negative attitudes toward hostage relief initiatives, such as that proposed by Tom Uren and Janine Haines, so as to conform with the United States Government's hard line in order to support its non-negotiating position? Secondly, does the Australian Government support the views expressed in the United States and in Britain that Iraq has to be militarily demolished even if it leaves Kuwait and that this would be tantamount to killing the monster that 30 countries from the West, the Soviet Bloc and the Third World all helped to create by unashamedly selling weapons to Iraq during the last decade? Thirdly, can the Government clarify its intentions if war breaks out in the Gulf? What would be the chain of command in the event of an armed conflict given the current de facto command position of the United States military?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of the question concerning hostages, the position taken by the Government-which has been explained by me on innumerable occasions and I do not propose to repeat all of that again now-is not one that has been determined by the United States or anyone else. It has been a position determined by the Australian Government on the basis of our best judgment and it is no different from the position adopted by just about every other country involved in this exercise. I remind Senator Vallentine and the Senate that the Economic Community Foreign Ministers, meeting in Rome on 16 November, unanimously reaffirmed their opposition to any form of official sanction for unilateral negotiations with Iraq for the release of hostages. It did not agree on the formal proscription of such visits, nor has Australia; but, as with us, there is simply no official encouragement being given to such visits for all of the obvious reasons that we have spelt out. The Japanese Government, again, has emphasised that former Japanese Prime Minister Nakasone's visit was private and Japan has restated its view that Iraq has to release all hostages unconditionally. The New Zealand Government's position on such visits is also totally consistent with ours.

ANSWER.PARA: I must emphasise that while there has been some success by private emissaries in these various `pilgrimages to the Baghdad bazaar'-as my Belgium foreign ministerial colleague put it-in securing the release of a number of hostages, in fact now some 500 of them, it has to be remembered that there are still around 4,000 west Europeans, Americans, Japanese, Australians and other nationals left and they are either detained at strategic installations-and there are still some 400 people in that category-or are otherwise unable to leave Iraq and Kuwait.

The main focus of our activity, acting in consort, conjunction, solidarity and coherence with the international community, has to be on putting pressure on Iraq to comply with its international legal obligation to release unconditionally and immediately, not just a handful of people from time to time to its own timetable and for its own propaganda advantage, but all foreign citizens.

With regard to the second part of the question about the objective of military demolition of Iraq being necessary to be accomplished, the situation is that the position of the United States and Britain, Australia for that matter and, to my knowledge everyone else participating in the Gulf exercise, is to ensure the success of the United Nations resolution-the United Nations Security Council's stated objectives. That does not require Iraq to be militarily demolished. The objective primarily is to ensure the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait, the restoration of the legitimate Government of Kuwait and the release of all foreign nationals who wish to leave. Our policy and that of these other countries in every case is toward achieving those objectives by peaceful means if that is humanly possible. If it cannot be achieved by peaceful means, we do have to contemplate the military option. It needs to be appreciated that the objectives have been deliberately cast in that form so as to not make necessary the military demolition of Iraq for the successful accomplishment of the Gulf task. The basic objectives that are spelt out in the Security Council resolution are objectives that are capable of being secured without full scale or any other military action.

It is, of course, crucial that in the aftermath of the Gulf crisis there be a reshaping, somehow, of the military balance of the region; and that there be some containment exercise or other security precautions put in place involving, preferably, large scale arms control agreements. But all of those things can be accomplished without the dramatic or comprehensive military down-sizing that some people seem to misunderstand to be part of the basic objectives of the international community. We believe that the core objectives, including the objective of a saner and safer security environment generally in the Middle East in the future, can be achieved by the effective and sustained application of economic sanctions by the international community.

As to the last question concerning Australia's position if a wider conflict occurs in the Gulf, I can only say again that the Government will need to make decisions on that matter in the circumstances applicable at the time. I do not propose to speculate now on what are merely hypothetical questions. The only point I further offer by way of correction is that there is not a current de facto command situation, so far as the United States military is concerned, in relation to the Australian ships. The truth of the matter is that Australian ships are operating under their own command. There are coordination arrangements, but Australian personnel and Australian ships are not subject to orders from any other country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and I ask him to clarify whether the Australian Government is attempting to ensure that there would be United Nations command in the event of the outbreak of hostilities. That position has not been clarified. I would also like him to spell out whether the Australian Government is prepared to withdraw support from the United States' provocative war preparation position, which does not give any credence any longer to a negotiated settlement in light of the disaffection with that position expressed recently by France, for example. I do not think the Minister can claim that there is total accord in the international community.
—Order! Senator, you cannot make a speech.
—I am asking the Minister two specific questions, Mr President.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, the Australian Government does not dissociate itself from the military preparations in which the United States and other countries participating in the Gulf are presently engaged, for the very obvious reason that it is very important indeed that Saddam Hussein understand that unless he does withdraw from the Gulf, unless he does respond to all the pressure that is put on him at the moment-which we hope will be successful in its own right through economic sanctions-there is inexorably and inevitably awaiting him at the end of the trail a military conflict, and a military conflict that he cannot win and must not win.

ANSWER.PARA: It is entirely appropriate that the international community, led in this instance by the United States, be engaging in the kind of preparation to ensure that message is communicated loud and clear. If Senator Vallentine, with her sense of hearing, cannot understand that message, I am unhappy for her, but I can assure her that it is a message that cannot now but have been heard by the Iraqi leadership and that, in the interests of peace and security in the Gulf, is what should be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that the Government will not dissociate itself from military preparations, my question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Can the Minister confirm that under section 10 of the National Service Act 1951 all that is required to reactivate conscription in this country is the publishing by the Minister-that is, the Minister for Defence-of a notice in the Gazette? Will the Minister explain why the Prime Minister failed to rule out the introduction of conscription in the event of war in the Middle East? Will the Minister explain the level of support that the Government is prepared to give President Bush if hostilities break out in the Middle East-in the light of the assurance we have just had from the Foreign Minister that the Government is prepared to participate in military preparations-and would this necessarily include conscripting young Australians? Will the Minister now rule out the introduction of conscription in the event of war breaking out in the Middle east?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been given a great example of someone sitting in a chair over there listening to my colleague, Senator Evans, and totally distorting and misleading this place about what Senator Evans said. Let me go to the first point raised by Senator McLean, and that is on the more technical nature. I have to say that his proposition is completely without substance. The national service scheme was abolished by administrative measures immediately after the election of the Whitlam Government in December 1972. An example of that was by the indefinite deferral of all obligations to register and by offering discharge to national servicemen in the Army. The National Service Act was not repealed at the time because some national servicemen continued to serve in the Army and it was necessary to keep the Act in force. However, the National Service Termination Bill 1973 was passed. This made it clear that no-one is liable to register or render service under the National Service Act.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clear beyond all doubt that the National Service Act could not be revived by any Executive or administrative action. Furthermore, all the provisions of the Defence Act which referred to national servicemen and included them in the composition of the Army were repealed by the last Defence Force Re-organisation Act 1975, after the last national serviceman left the Army. It is perfectly plain that the National Service Act is completely defunct. There is no way it could be revived, except by a substantial legislative exercise-that is, if anyone wanted to revive it.

The second part of Senator McLean's question asked why the Prime Minister has not ruled it out. I simply ask the question: Why should the Prime Minister waste his time chasing down every idiotic press release that the Australian Democrats put out? I could easily come into this place and be provocative and call the Democrats lackeys of Saddam Hussein if only to get a bit of publicity, et cetera, but I do not do so. I try to play politics at least in a rational way. But the Democrats' exercises over the last two days have been real cheap shots, especially the statement by their Leader yesterday. They have sat down and thought, `How can we jack up this issue and get some publicity? Let's reintroduce the conscription issue'.

As to the question: Will we reintroduce subscription?, the answer is no. Senator McLean also asked us to speculate on what this Government's reaction would be to a set of future and hypothetical situations. I will not give an answer to that other than assure him that we look at every scenario in advance and plan accordingly. But it is not proper, and no-one would expect us to do so, to publicly announce what we would do today if hostilities broke out in the Middle East in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support advise the Senate of the actions taken to save six lives which were threatened when yachts got into difficulties off northern Australia last week?
—This is how you are handing out Dorothy Dixers today, eh?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was Senator Devereux's question, not mine. I am glad, in response to Senator Hill's interjection, to be given this question because it gives me an opportunity, once again, to stress something publicly that is very important for people going to sea in small boats, particularly--
—He has done something.

—It is a matter of particular relevance to the State of Tasmania that Senator Walters represents. It is very important for people going to sea in small boats, particularly when they are responsible for the lives of others, as was the case here-two young children-to make sure that they go to sea equipped with a satellite compatible EPIRB; that is, an emergency position indicating radio beacon. The only way they can be certain of that is to make sure they have purchased one of these beacons since June this year. Prior to June, the EPIRBs that were produced were for terrestrial systems. Some were produced for satellite systems and, regrettably, some people are still under the impression that all of them are satellite compatible. They are not. The consequences could be tragic for people that are still under that impression. The only way that people can be certain they have EPIRBs that are compatible with the new satellite system that has been in use since late last year is to have purchased these EPIRBs at a cost of just over $200 since June this year.

ANSWER.PARA: In the two cases that occurred on the same day last week, both gave very dramatic point to how successful this system is in saving lives. Both incidents occurred on Thursday last week. In the first a satellite signal was transmitted to the ground station at Alice Springs and then transmitted to the Sea Safety Centre in Canberra from a yacht which was stranded near Osprey Reef in the Coral Sea.

A Coastwatch aircraft, that is a coastal surveillance aircraft, was dispatched immediately by the Sea Safety Centre and discovered a man and two young children stranded on that sinking yacht. They were winched off the yacht by helicopter and landed at Cairns, and their lives were thereby saved. In a second incident on the same day a Cathay Pacific airliner over the Gulf of Carpentaria in northern Australia reported hearing distress signals from an EPIRB. These signals were confirmed by a second aircraft and almost immediately afterwards the exact position of the yacht was pinpointed by the satellite system and transmitted to Canberra. Again, a coastal surveillance aircraft was immediately dispatched and successfully located the yacht. On this occasion two vessels were diverted and took the yacht in tow. As a result six lives were saved which otherwise may well have been-in the case of one of the yachts they certainly would have been-lost. I take this opportunity again to stress that all people going to sea in boats should make the very modest investment of a little over $200 and make sure they have an EPIRB which was purchased after June this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the answer to a question without notice given by the Minister last Wednesday which referred to a possible Prices Surveillance Authority inquiry into the level of executive salary increases that he said were in the range of 16.5 per cent. Will such an inquiry include in its terms of reference those senior staff in his and other ministerial offices who have received salary increases of up to 35 per cent, plus additional fringe benefits? If not, why not? Is the level of salary increase there more than double the level of increase in the private sector to which the Minister referred?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this chamber there have been some cheap shots and we have just seen another of them. In respect of the Prices Surveillance Authority, I propose to have a discussion with the responsible Minister, Mr Simon Crean, about whether the PSA can in fact require there to be shown in applications before the Prices Surveillance Authority what the level of executive remuneration is, and have that clearly reported so a comparison can be made between the wage restraint being conducted by ordinary Australian wage and salary earners within the guidelines of the Industrial Relations Commission wage fixing principles and what, on the evidence, appears to be rapacious rip-offs by some senior executives in some companies. Where those rip-offs are the case and a particular company or industry is applying for price increases-that is, applying to pass on the rip-offs to consumers in the form of higher prices-those rip-offs should be reduced out of any price increases. That is what I am proposing to do and I look forward to having those discussions with Simon Crean shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: The cheap shot comes in the second part of the question about ministerial staff. The adjustments to ministerial staff are in the province of Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Administrative Services. The adjustments were determined according to the appropriate wage fixing principles after a substantial period in which the salaries of that class of officer had not been reviewed. If the increases are larger than would normally be the case, it is to do with the fact that there has been a significant delay in review for this class of officer and no provision over that time for the adjustments that appropriately ought to have been made.

The last point I make about this is that since it has been within the guidelines, the level of remuneration that has been referred to-and I have seen some reports in the press-has been fixed so there is an upper and a lower level of the range. Where the performance of ministerial staff members is properly assessed, they are then placed within the range so there is a recognition of their performance and an incentive for continued and improved performance. There is also a recognition of the hours they work and the type of obligations and responsibilities they bear and the right remuneration is paid for those types of penalties as well.

There is absolutely no comparison case on a level of staff remuneration-which is not only for ministerial staff but, I point out, for staff of the Leader of the Opposition as well-between that which is within the wage fixing principles properly assessed, properly determined and properly placed, and the self-awarded salary increases for senior executives in this country who say of ordinary wage and salary earners, `Do as we tell you to do; do not do as we do'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Who makes the assessment, or is this just a case of the spoils of office that the Minister has referred to on so many occasions in this place?

—This is a canary question. It is cheap in the first instance and it is cheap in the second instance, so what we get from the Opposition is cheap, cheap. The assessment is made by the appropriate officers of the Department of Industrial Relations with no reference to any Minister whatsoever.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. It concerns the number of complaints I have received regarding insurance and the insurance industry. What steps is the Government taking, if any, to address what are very legitimate complaints of consumers about the insurance industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives receive representations from policyholders and those who have made application for insurance, but particularly claimants under various insurance contracts, which reveal first of all a difficulty in the comprehension of the terms of the various arrangements they are asked to enter into, and then, of course, when making a claim, a difficulty in pursuing that claim where the insurance company resists the ordinary expectation of the holder of the policy to a payment.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, there have been various moves within the insurance industry over the last year to try to come to grips with these complaints and to provide a system whereby complaints could be handled in an expeditious, fair and impartial manner. To that end, both the Life Insurance Federation of Australia (LIFA) and the Insurance Council of Australia, dealing respectively with life assurance and general insurance, have been devising a scheme to provide for the resolution of such complaints. That particular scheme, I hope, will be in place if not by the end of this year then early next year.

Honourable senators will be aware that the operation of the Industry Ombudsman has already been a very successful operation. The banks have constituted Mr McDonald as the Banking Industry Ombudsman to oversee the complaint resolution process operating throughout the banking system in Australia. There is no need to slavishly adopt that particular model, but it is important that the life insurance and the general insurance industries do provide a complaint resolution process. I hope that with further consultation with consumer groups, which is being undertaken at this very moment by LIFA and by the Insurance Council of Australia, a system of complaint resolution can be established that will have the confidence of policyholders and the insurance companies-and both sides need to have confidence in the process.

I understand also that in relation to certain superannuation, which is another cause of some confusion and concern in the Australian community as superannuation becomes more widely available throughout the community, particularly, as we know, with the very successful extension of superannuation entitlements to workers under their awards, the Treasurer has indicated that he will be promulgating regulations which will disclose more about the promotional and administrative fees which are involved in the provision of superannuation. I believe that that will be very satisfactory from the point of view of those out in the community, to which Senator Crowley refers.

In addition in that matter I have asked the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, headed by Justice Paul Stein, to look at the question of superannuation and consumers because this will be a matter of growing concern over the coming decade as more and more Australians have the benefit and entitlement to this particular provision. In answer to Senator Crowley, I would say that there is a considerable amount of activity in relation to resolving disputes and complaints between insurance companies and consumers and I believe that we are well on the way to having a fair, impartial and expeditious system of resolution of these disputes being constituted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate. Was the Minister or his then Department of Immigration responsible for initiating the proposal for his Department to spend additional funds on the grant in aid scheme, the migrant access project scheme and supplementation for the pilot access and equity projects amounting to $2.75m immediately before the last Federal election, which was described in the Minister's submission, I understand, as an election ploy; or did the proposals originate in the Office of Multicultural Affairs within the Prime Minister's Department? Why were the pilot access and equity projects one-off grants? Did they originate from detailed submissions with stated objectives and criteria for review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in an awkward position not because of the question but because of the portfolio responsibility that it covers. It is not normal in this chamber that one answers questions on one's previous portfolio. I must say that that is very frustrating at times. It is a very frustrating process that one disciplines oneself not to comment outside the Cabinet room on other portfolio areas. We do not have the same restraints placed on us within Cabinet where, with a lot of ex-Ministers, it is a long meeting.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it quite clear to Senator Michael Baume that any submission I brought forward was absolutely my own submission. Any of the arguments I put in Cabinet in favour of that submission were well based. There was a requirement in terms of the pilot equity and access projects (PEAP) scheme where we were following a policy of gradually easing out established grants in aid. When grant in aid was first instituted, it was meant to be a temporary three-year thing under the previous Government. What it became was an institutionalised, always renewable grant. What that tended to do was bottle up grants in established communities. As the Government moved its policy away from established communities to where the grant in aid scheme was regarded as essential, that is, to the newer communities, certain gaps were created that were undesirable in some of the more established communities, especially some of those that had ageing communities because they then had different needs apart from the new settlers. That was the origin of the PEAP scheme. It was not meant to be a scheme that lasted for several years. It did not start during that Cabinet submission, incidentally, but many, many months before. It was announced and Senator Baume would have first come across it when I answered questions here and in Estimates Committee about dealings with the Ombudsman.

On the other two matters that were in that submission and got funding, one was the migrant access project (MAP) scheme. The intention of that particular scheme was: are grants in aid the most appropriate way or can we move to project funding? I think that there is a strong argument for project funding because at least it gets round the problem that every grant has to be automatically renewed politically. I do not mean in a partisan way; I mean that once a grant is given, it is very hard to take it away. Therefore, the MAP scheme was an experimental scheme to go to project funding rather than personnel funding.

On the final matter of an increase in grants in aid-I enthusiastically supported that for the 20 months in which I was Minister for Immigration, again to try to break that bottleneck and to try to get some grants in aid to the very newly arrived ethnic communities, and there are many of them. It was my belief that by the established communities bottling up those grants in aid we were failing to get money to very desperately needed areas. I had no hesitation in supporting that Cabinet submission. It was my initiative and it is one of which I am quite proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his assurance, implicit in his response, that the initiative did not originate in the Office of Multicultural Affairs of the Prime Minister's Department. I ask him: In that case, would he please deny or reject the statement by the Department of Finance in its response to the request by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs for more money that the request was made for these matters `following discussions with the Prime Minister, apparently in response to pressure from established ethnic communities for access to Immigration Department grants'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —A thorough search of the Immigration Department records will show that the aim of both the PEAP scheme and the MAP scheme and my intention throughout the 20 months that I was Immigration Minister was to increase grants in this particular area. All sorts of input comes in, but I stress that the initiative was mine and not theirs. They do, of course, feed in. I also have to caution the honourable senator on the veracity of Finance coordinating comments over the years. Often I have not found them to be as well based as they should be. That seems to be the case irrespective of who the Finance Minister is because nothing has changed in the last few months.

ANSWER.PARA: I have to stress that it is the Finance Department's job to play the devil's advocate, to put the blow torch to every submission that comes before Cabinet and to use every tactic possible to test rather than to assert. I think that part of its process was to put those remarks in to test that particular process. Sure, the Office of Multicultural Affairs has always consulted on those particular matters to get a view because it also deals in a hands on way. It is also necessary to make sure that grants are not being duplicated, et cetera. The Office of Multicultural Affairs tends to be research oriented and its grants are research oriented and one must coordinate between the two so that there is not an overlap. Yes, I understand what the Department of Finance said. I do not believe that it was properly based.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Can the Minister inform the Senate of what is being done to retain the natural Australian rural landscape, given concerns being expressed that landholders are planting too many exotic trees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The management of Australia's landscape has obviously been a problem for longer than just the last few years because in 200 years we have managed to remove an extraordinary percentage of our tree cover and in attempting to replace it over the next few years Australians will need to be careful about the way they go about it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has recognised just how severe these problems are and has put in place a number of initiatives. They include: the Landcare program, which included the Landcare year 1990 and the Decade of Landcare for the year 2000 and an expansion of the national soil conservation program, the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation, and the Murray-Darling Basin natural resources management strategy and revegetation program, which include the national afforestation program, the save the bush program and, importantly, the billion trees program.

Firstly, it is not the case that we can attempt to ban the planting of exotic trees. Obviously the planting of pines will have some effect over time on pressure on our native forests and, far from discouraging it, we should be encouraging it. By the same token, it is often a matter of where they are placed. I am not sure that we have always been terribly careful about their position.

Secondly, it is still the case that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is experimenting even with some exotic species. As an example, on the New England tablelands, it is still experimenting with species which will give protection, especially as windbreaks, during those harsh New England winters. I do not rule out the fact that there may be localised uses for some of these exotic species. Nonetheless, I think through some uninformed land management practices there are some landholders in Australia who are planting exotic trees where it is not appropriate. Greening Australia will be working with many groups in the community, including the Australian Institute of Horticulture and the Society for Growing Australian Plants, to try to raise awareness. I think all any of us can do is make sure that we caution landholders that where they are planting trees, if it is possible to plant a native, they ought to go for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the recent Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service discussion paper on the importation of bananas from Ecuador, in which it was noted that moko was one of the most devastating diseases affecting bananas. Given that Ecuadorian authorities have said that another dangerous disease, black sigatoka, did not exist in that country when the Quarantine and Inspection Service found that it did, what credence can be given to Ecuadorian claims to have implemented strict quarantine measures on moko? Further, is it not true that any bananas imported from Ecuador could potentially bring moko into this country, thus endangering a very important north Queensland industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I am in a position to answer all of the details about moko, if that be the proper name of the disease. However, I am aware that the Australian banana industry has approached the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) expressing its concern at the likely disease risk if Ecuadorian bananas are permitted entry to Australia. In late 1989 AQIS received a proposal from Fruit Distributors Ltd, Wellington, New Zealand, to permit importation of fresh banana fruit from Ecuador. This company has been importing Ecuadorian bananas into New Zealand for a number of years and wishes to extend its operation to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: AQIS has received information on banana pests and diseases from the Ecuadorian Ministry of Agriculture and, as a consequence, has prepared a preliminary risk assessment and discussion paper for the October 1990 Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service bulletin. The review is still preliminary but the industry will be kept fully informed of developments in this proposal and will be given the opportunity to contribute to the technical assessment.

It will be several months before AQIS is in a position to determine whether a detailed bio-economic study will be required and a final decision is not expected before at least the latter half of 1991. Industry has responded to the AQIS discussion paper by convening meetings in New South Wales and Queensland with participants from growers, from transport representatives and from representatives of the packaging, marketing and horticultural industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Cook for reading a prepared answer which, of course, does not answer my question. I ask him once again whether he is willing to comment on the credence that can be given to Ecuadorian claims that it has implemented strict quarantine measures on moko when its other claims in respect of black sigatoka have been shown to be patently false.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the hint might have been taken that we are at arm's length from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.
—Aren't you the Government?

—Well, it means that there is a separation of powers at this point. Queenslanders may not understand what the separation of powers might mean. Indeed, the former National Party Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, could not answer what the doctrine of the separation of powers was when it was put to him on television. That may be a Queensland disease for which there ought to be quarantine protection from the rest of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: However, let me go back and say that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service operates independent of government in these matters, and it is appropriate that it should do so because there should be no political interference at all in the technical assessment of whether or not there is a quarantine risk from the importation of whatever item or substance into Australia.

Senator O'Chee is inviting me to express an opinion on an opinion-moreover, on an opinion which is currently the subject of a discussion paper released by the independent Quarantine and Inspection Service so that scientific analysis can be made and the opinion of grower organisations can be taken. I think in all of those circumstances, it is entirely appropriate and, moreover, responsible for me, as a representative Minister to say that any concerns about that disease, which I expect to be real concerns-particularly in view of the way in which the honourable senator may be adding to the speculation about it-should be properly taken up within the ambit of the opportunity provided by the Quarantine and Inspection Service. Indeed, the fact that the Service has released its discussion paper has in a logical and rational way programmed for informed discussion and analysis that very question, among others. It is inappropriate for me to make a special comment at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of reports that the Government is considering removing environmental controls on forests which are designated for logging so that they would not be subject to environmental impact assessments, National Estate or World Heritage evaluation, or any other type of Federal Government intervention on environmental grounds? Do the resource security measures being considered by the Government include any diminution at all of any environmental protection measures already in place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, resource security has been in the forefront of discussions between the Commonwealth and the States during the past few months. After deliberations by a ministerial committee, the Government decided last month to put forward a set of processes to be implemented in consultation with the States regarding resource security.

ANSWER.PARA: The measures involve the development of bilateral agreements with States and assessment of suitable regions for long term resource security. Those assessments would cover environmental, heritage, cultural, social and economic considerations. The measures recognised that proposals for resource security will emanate from the States, as they have the primary responsibility for determining land use and management. The Commonwealth would assess and respond to these proposals.

Further discussions are to be held between Ministers and with States and other interested parties regarding the exact means of ensuring an adequate level of resource security and a clear set of resource, conservation and development regimes. The processes and means being proposed by the Government do not involve amendment to the Australian Heritage Commission Act. Such amendment is not considered a real or desirable option.

It should be noted that, following discussions in Brisbane, it was agreed that the proposed intergovernmental agreement on the environment would aim to embrace the development of these improved processes for assessment for forest resources. These would provide for both the conservation of Australia's forest heritage and long term resource security. These processes could include complementary Commonwealth and State legislation where requested by States and, importantly, agreed upon by the Commonwealth. This Government will not be watering down its environmental assessment procedures and its efforts to protect Australia's natural environment. But it will be looking as to how the processes can be improved to facilitate investment by industry. This matter is firmly before the Government for further consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. With reference to the sailing of the HMAS Brisbane and HMAS Sydney to replace HMAS Adelaide and HMAS Darwin on station in the Gulf of Oman, and the later dispatch of HMAS Westralia, why are the ships being replaced, given that the deployment by historic precedent is very brief, being only about 12 weeks on patrol and 19 weeks in total away from the port of Sydney? Has any detailed costing been done and, if not, will it be done on the total cost of the changeover, not only for the steaming time to get to and from the patrol area, but for outfitting Brisbane and Sydney and any other relevant costs? Was any consideration given to flying fresh crews into the theatre? If consideration was given, why was it rejected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 12-week period of being on station is the best available judgment according to the Royal Australian Navy and its recommendation to me. It is also desirable, if possible, to rotate crews. Senator MacGibbon by his third question would agree with that. If crews were simply rotated through to two strange ships, it would do much to break down the traditions and crew loyalty to a particular ship. That would not be desirable.

ANSWER.PARA: Twelve weeks is about the right period, in my own judgment, having seen everything that has come across my desk. It could have been longer. There is no operational reason that it could not have been a little longer. Nevertheless, that is a fair thing, given the steaming time of three weeks either way means that the crews are away from home and family for a substantial time.

On the question of costs, I do not have those readily available to me. Getting the steaming time costs will not be too difficult. I will provide those at another time. I reject the concept of just leaving the two ships in the Gulf and rotating the crews as it goes too much against the traditions of the Navy. If the rotation related to the Royal Australian Air Force, we could have done that. Unless we recognise and support some of these traditions, much of the esprit de corps would disappear.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to the fact that the Australian Customs Service is moving out of the historically and aesthetically important Customs House in Hobart. Is it planned to retain the building in Commonwealth hands or to dispose of it? If the latter, at what stage is the disposal process? Being aware that the State Government may be interested in taking over the building if the terms are right and being aware of the widely held view that it ought to be used to allow for the expansion of the adjacent Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery and to allow the incorporation in the building of the Maritime Museum in this important part of Sullivan's Cove, I ask the Minister whether he will agree to take all possible action to ensure the long term preservation of Customs House in public ownership?

—The building that Senator Coates referred to is a heritage building. It is on the register of the National Estate. He is also right when he refers to the Tasmanian Government's strong interest in acquiring the Customs House, in essence to preserve its heritage value and, of course, for its potential use as part of the Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery. As Senator Coates would know, the Customs House has been long used by the Australian Customs Service, but it has recently found new accommodation. It expects to relocate there by the end of this year. Given the heritage nature of the building, and given the interest and value placed on its preservation by the State Government, I am pleased to be able to reveal to Senator Coates and the Senate that my Department is keen to negotiate its sale to the State of Tasmania. In fact, officers of the Department of Administrative Services are currently negotiating with the Tasmanian Government and discussing arrangements for the sale to proceed. I cannot say any more at this stage other than to indicate that I am keen to expedite this matter and to ensure that the heritage value of the building is preserved in the hands of the Tasmanian State Government. I also hope that an announcement can be made in the near future.

—I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to a question I asked him on 18 October 1990 on centralised purchasing. From his response, it was clear he did not have a clue what I was talking about. As he has had sufficient time to review that question, I again ask him: How does he reconcile the ideological move to centralised purchasing with the financial management improvement program? What does he understand is the meaning and purpose of the financial management improvement program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We, on this side of the Parliament, are used to free kicks from the Opposition. We seem to be getting them continually. I start answering Senator Parer's question by referring to one important part of the Government's purchasing program and that was of course a seminar and exposition which was organised and held in Canberra last week. Senator Parer seems to be concerned that we are moving to some Soviet bloc-based system of purchasing and control in purchasing. He could be no further from the truth. One great example of what we did was a `meet the buyers' exposition last week and one great example of where Senator Parer is out on his own and isolated, was the great turn up of Australian businesses at that particular exposition. This exhibition was organised by my Department and the small business unit in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It also attracted private sponsorship. It was in fact a reverse trade fair, based on the principle that those--
—That is not the question I asked you.
—Senator Parer is getting more than the answer he expected, and he will get a lot more than that as well. In this reverse trade fair, instead of the usual arrangements--
—He is terrified.

—He might be terrified; he asks two questions every six months. Government buyers were at this reverse trade fair to meet with industry and to show to industry what they were concerned about, what they want to buy and how they operate.
—Why don't you go and learn about your portfolio?

—Senator Parer is getting a full answer, and the longer he interjects, the longer I will have to go. `Meet the buyers' was a program which not only reduced the mystery of doing business with government and providing a one-stop opportunity to meet government purchasers but also, and more importantly, allowed industry to understand where government reforms in purchasing had gone and have been going. It was a successful exhibition. We had about 2,000 people there on the first day. As I said, the important part of it was to provide a very unique opportunity for industry to understand where government purchasing has been and will be going.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Parer was there for a while and it is quite obvious that in his time there he understood very little. One of the most important things to come out of the exhibition was that the Government's purchasing policy based on the principle of value for money was explained to industry. In that context a very basic principle of government looking for sophisticated equipment and looking for industry to meet those sorts of quality needs was also explained. Industry understood quite well that the State and Federal governments' $30 billion purchasing power can be used quite effectively to assist domestic industry to compete for work domestically and also to put it in a great position to compete internationally.

This is very far from the allegation that Senator Parer makes that what we are moving towards is a centralised Soviet bloc system of purchasing. We have decentralised. Purchasing has been devolved into two individual government departments. The sooner the Opposition understands that that is the direction of purchasing policy and also that industry out in the broad Australian community is responding to it, then the sooner it will get back into the mainstream of Australian politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: What does he understand is the meaning and purpose of the financial management improvement program? Does he not understand that centralised purchasing and the financial management improvement program are diametrically opposed?

—It is a pity that this question was not asked earlier in Question Time because there is quite a comprehensive answer. I just repeat my point: if Senator Parer cannot understand that what has happened in government purchasing in the last three or four years has been a devolution of purchasing power to individual purchasing officers in departments, he really cannot understand what is going on.

—I have a response to a question asked by Senator Alston on 8 November concerning the reissuing of family allowance forms. It is expected that the full cost of sending out revised forms will therefore be less than $100,000. If my Department had deferred commencing its usual annual review until legislation had been passed by the Parliament, the entitlements of about 1.9 million families would not have been established for 1991 by the first pay day in January.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 November Senator Bell asked me a question relating to details of initiatives undertaken to facilitate export sales of particular commodities. He asked me for examples. I have 3 1/2 pages of them which I would rather not read out. I seek permission to have them incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SALES OF RURAL PRODUCE
On 6 November, Senator Bell asked me a question relating to details of initiatives undertaken to facilitate export sales of rural commodities. Examples of the Government's actions include:
GATT

At the same time as Australia has sought stronger disciplines for trade in agricultural products in the Uruguay Round, the existing GATT rules have been used to further sales of Australian rural produce.

As a result of the successful GATT challenge against the Republic of Korea's import regime for beef, brought by Australia, New Zealand and the United States, and subsequent bilateral access negotiations with Korea, the Korean beef market has been expanded.

The beef access arrangements with Korea follow on from the successful conclusion in 1988 of the Japan beef access arrangements. These arrangements followed negotiations to which Japan had agreed after Australia and other countries had initiated a challenge within the GATT. By these arrangements Japan agreed to successively larger import quotas for beef.

Australia has mounted a successful challenge against US sugar import quotas. We are disappointed that the changes that the US has made to its import regime in response have only been cosmetic ones. However, we will continue to press strongly for a more market-oriented sugar program. This will, if appropriate, include further action within the GATT.
MINISTERIAL VISITS AND REPRESENTATIONS
US
Over the past 12 months, Australia has made intensive efforts to press for a more market oriented 1990 US Farm Bill
Dr Blewett and Mr Kerin have made representations during their visits to Washington and most recently Senator Evans raised Australian concerns at the October US/Australia Ministerial talks.
Middle East

During August this year, Dr Blewett led a delegation of 37 Australian business representatives and government officials to the three-day Australia Iran Joint Commission, which he chaired with the Iranian Minister for Agriculture which resulted in
initialling of a new Trade Agreement between Australia and Iran, providing a framework for the conduct of future bilateral trade
signing of a Veterinary Sanitary Agreement which will facilitate the further development, stability and predictability of trade in sheepmeat from Australia to Iran.
negotiation by business of contracts which will boost annual export by some $100m a year, including sales of wheat and mutton.
Mr Kerin's visit to the Middle East earlier this year included discussions on formal agreements with Oman and the United Arab Emirates on veterinary requirements for sheep.
EC

Our agricultural trade access concerns with the EC have been raised on number of occasions by Ministers during the year, including by Mr Duffy and Dr Blewett during their various visits to Brussels and EC capitals, and by Senator Evans and Mr Kerin at the EC/Australia Ministerial Consultations in Brussels in June. Representations on the Andriessen Assurance have been made by the Prime Minister personally to the President of the EC Commission, Delors.
During 1990 we have pressed the EC for
an increase in Australia's high quality beef quota
an increase in our sheepmeat voluntary restraint agreement quota
agreement to grant access to Australian manufacturing mutton
reassurance that it would not revoke the 1985 Andriessen Assurance by which the EC refrains from exporting its subsidised beef to Japan, Korea and other key Asian and Pacific markets
real reform of the Common Agricultural Policy
Wool

Mr Kerin will be leading a Government/Industry Wool Mission to West Europe (Milan/Paris), Moscow, Korea, Japan (Osaka/Tokyo) and Beijing from 17 November to 2 December. The objective of the Mission is to make an overall assessment of the wool market, future prospects and timing of recovery
Mr Kerin will be accompanied by senior industry representatives
he will also be discussing the question of credit with the Soviet Union to maintain our important commodity trade with that country.
COMMODITY TRADE AGREEMENT

The Government signed an agreement with the Soviet Union in February this year to provide a more stable basis for exports to the USSR. The indicative quantities listed for the terms of the Agreement include:
Wheat: 2 million tonnes over three years;
Butter: 37,500 tonnes over three years;
Greasy Wool: 260,000 tonnes over three years;
Sugar: 300,000 tonnes over three years:
as well as mutton, barley and protein crops.
GOVERNMENT RURAL INDUSTRY ASSISTANCE
Innovative Agricultural Marketing Program (IAMP)

The Program is providing $20m over five years as assistance to producers, processors, manufacturers and marketers in Australia's agricultural, forestry and fishing industries. Priority areas for funding include improvements in handling, storage, transport, packaging, distribution and marketing techniques for Australia's fisheries, meat, dairy, horticultural and forestry industries.
Export Marketing Skills Program (EMSP)

The Program is upgrading the export marketing skills of agriculture and allied industries by establishing centres of excellence in export marketing, in co-operation with industry, and by supporting action orientated training. In 1989-90, $2m was provided to 7 training projects and 2 centres of excellence in export marketing skills. Training was provided in export marketing for dairy, horticulture, viticulture, food processing, fisheries and timber industries.
Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC)

EFIC facilities are aimed at encouraging Australia's exports, international project work and investment through insurance, guarantees and indemnities and loans. Commodities constitute the largest proportion of exports insured by EFIC. In 1989/90, traditional exports including meat, dairy products, wheat, hides and skins and wool accounted for around 70% of exports credit-insured.

TALK.START.PARA: — Just last week Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question relating to the move to 100 per cent cost recovery for services provided by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS). I am now able to give a full answer to that question. The full recovery of user attributable services is consistent with the user pays principle and it encourages more efficient use of resources. The Opposition in its Economic Action Plan supports the concept of user pays. Since the 1988 Policy for Growth statement, the 1989 Industries Assistance Commission report on the food processing and beverages industries recommended full cost recovery for inspection services.

ANSWER.PARA: A comprehensive review of all AQIS charges and charging systems is being undertaken in consultation with industry over the next 12 months to ensure that charges are equitable and the most administratively efficient. In association with the introduction of higher charges, the Government is funding a number of measures to facilitate changes in industry practices which will minimise the cost of inspection and quarantine services. These will include relief for small-scale domestic meat processors and encouraging new participants into the export sector. Revised charges reflecting the 100 per cent cost recovery will be announced on 15 November 1990 for introduction on 1 January 1991.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:

(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: NSW Aboriginal Deaths in Custody Watch Committee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned Australian petitioners call on the Australian Government to take real steps to prevent the abuse of human rights of Aboriginals in prison and police custody.

A Royal Commission was set up to find out in general terms why so many Aborigines die in custody and the circumstances surrounding each death before the Commission. We, the petitioners, would like to express the following concerns:

1. Aboriginal families and organisations have not received adequate funding from the Federal Government to ensure adequate representation. Yet the Commission faces constant challenge from the powerful police and prison officers' unions in their efforts to shut down the inquiry.

2. The Royal Commission's interim report includes recommendations for changes in custodial practices. Yet only some of the recommendations have been implemented, and only in some places-no government body is monitoring the implementation and the deaths continue.
3. The occurrence of racist attacks, that is: David Gundy was killed in his home by the Police SWOS. The Coroner's Court verdict on his killing was `death by accident'.
We call for a just inquiry into Aboriginal deaths in custody.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigrants : Discrimination
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That although Australia claims to have adopted a non-discriminatory policy in respect to immigrants, yet this policy discriminates against those who have been responsible for development of Australia, the Anglo-Celtic majority who compose 75% of the population now, by the deliberate selection of immigrants from areas from which Anglo-Keltic peoples are not likely to be obtained. At the same time although the Asian percentage of the population of Australia is 4.5% of the population yet Asian immigrants are represented by between 40% and 55.5% of the immigrant intake. Evidence is enclosed.
Continuation of this policy must eventually alter the ethnic composition of Australia and increase the possibility of racial strife as in Sri Lanka, Fiji and other well known areas of racial strife.

Your petitioners therefore request that immigrants be obtained from areas which will tend to maintain the ethnic structure of Australia as notified in National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia page 2.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patenting
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate.
The undersigned citizens of Australia oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would:

compromise animal welfare, allow genetic engineering companies to appropriate the fruits of centuries of selective breeding, reduce biodiversity, and further concentrate ownership of breeding stock. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Therefore, please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more.
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We urge the members of the Australian Senate to act on this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The Treasury annual report is always an interesting and important document as the Treasury, of course, acts as the principal economic adviser to the Treasurer and hence to the Government. The 1989-90 annual report tabled today is a comprehensive report and has much very useful and important information in it.

It is interesting to note that in 1988-89 the Treasury in various ways increased both its functions and its responsibilities. In particular, it has stepped up its role in the area of consideration of micro-economic reform in the last 12 months. It has traditionally, of course, been the adviser on macro-economic reform.

Importantly, it has also stepped up its consideration of environmental issues. I welcome that development very much because I believe that the Treasury has an important input to make to the debate on environmental issues, to help get a balance between the straight environmental issues and the economic issues when we look at the whole question of environmental policy generally.
Tabling of Documents

The Treasury has also played an important role in the last financial year 1989-90 in the area of retirement incomes and superannuation policy. In that financial year we saw a major change in the superannuation policy and programs of the Commonwealth Public Service. Last year a public debt management policy became increasingly important. On the other hand-and I regret this-the Treasury ceased responsibility for the preparation of the monthly Treasury Round-up. That was a very important statistical document commenting each month on the state of affairs.

As far as I have been able to ascertain from the Parliamentary Library, the Australian Bureau of Statistics has not begun production of a publication which has a coverage anything like the Round-up but which was, at the time of the cessation of the Round-up, said to be imminent. I for one relied on the Treasury Round-up as a major source of useful statistical information and I hope that the Bureau of Statistics will get on to the job of supplementing that quickly. If not, I hope its decision to discontinue the Round-up will be reveiwed.

Try as it might, even with the Treasury's expanded role, it has had little success with micro-economic reform. The Treasurer has continually been rolled by other Ministers. Mr Beazley, for example, has abjectly defeated the Treasurer on the whole question of communications reform. We have welcomed the reform moves generally in the micro area but Treasury's preferred line seems to be becoming increasingly isolated as senior Ministers-Senator Button in this chamber, Mr Dawkins and others-call for selective industry assistance and a reassessment of the Treasury's approach to economic policy. I believe that that is a very worrying trend. That is one of the most significant trends that has happened within Government circles in recent weeks and the selective breaking of the Government line by senior Ministers in their public statements in this area augurs very seriously, I believe, not only for the Government but also for the Treasurer himself.

There have been a number of addresses by Treasury officers on macro-economic issues. I welcome that. I think that is a very useful role. The macro-economic policy role and its whole process has obviously gone off the rails. There is increasing tension between Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia over the direction and reliance on monetary policy by the Government. I have spoken at length on this in recent times. I will not do it again other than to raise the main issue, namely, a major fiscal policy blow-out. We are more on track now than ever with the reckless and profligate increase in Government spending that was announced by the Government in the Budget. The forecasts for the year ahead on which the Budget was based are now out of line with reality. The unemployment figures, the inflation figures-despite last week's figure-and other forecasts have really blown the relevance of the Budget out of the water. That is a matter that will be of continuing importance in debates in the weeks ahead.

This report is an example of a report of excellence. There are few reports tabled in this place which provide more useful information than the one before us today. I urge all senators to avail themselves of this report because the Industry Commission has outlined in a most comprehensive way the failure of this Government's economic policies and, more particularly, the failure of Senator Button's industry policy to bring about sustainable benefits for consumers, taxpayers, manufacturers or exporters.

Despite the Government's reluctance to use the `R' word-indeed in this morning's press some people are talking about the use of the `D' word; of course, those two words are recession and depression respectively-the Industry Commission outlines the poor state of the economy. At page 3 of the report there is a worthy quote. It states:
The economy has been burdened with persistent inflation, a build up of foreign debt and, despite strong employment growth, continuing unemployment.
Further it states:

. . . the constraints that the Australian economy currently faces leave us particularly vulnerable to a turnaround in world commodity prices. If the terms of trade decline . . . our ability to maintain living standards will come under strong pressure.
This report amounts to a rap over the knuckles for the Treasurer who is told by the Commission:
We should not judge our performance against the standard of the past. We must consider what other countries are achieving.

That then becomes a very interesting yardstick. The Commission shows that agriculture is the only Australian sector performing better than other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries and that electricity, gas and water utilities combined have productivity levels half that of other OECD countries. The Commission identifies precisely which areas are in need of micro-economic reform and precisely the extent of likely benefits to Australians. Micro reform could bring Australia an additional $22 billion in gross domestic product, 53,000 additional jobs, a reduction in the price level of 7 per cent and make Australian households better off to the tune of $2,300 a year.

The Commission reiterates precisely what I have been advocating in this chamber, which is that Senator Button's policies have failed to invigorate Australian industry, and the report states how Australia's credibility has been undermined by provision of such assistance as the Kodak bounty. The sort of bedtime reading that this report could make for the Minister concerned could be of assistance to Australia generally. The Commission demolishes the argument that strategic trade theorists use, and at page 64 the report states:
. . . industry-specific assistance far from being a prerequisite for success is likely to be harmful, especially if it is extensive and maintained over long periods.

This report is an excellent compendium for the case for free trade. I would recommend it as good reading for all those who are touched from time to time with the need for governments to become interventionist. Generally, I must say that I am impressed with the report but I am very disappointed at the way in which this Government has hounded Dr Allan Moran from the Commission for daring to put a point of view which differed from his Government's. I can only say that I hope Tony Cole does not meet with the same fate.

—On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 9 of 1990-91, Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Antarctic supply, vessel chartering arrangements.
