This is an audit report into what has clearly been a mess. The Government really has little to smile about on the question of the building of an Antarctic supply vessel and the contracts that surround it. Many questions have been asked in Senate Estimates committees for some time over this matter. Basically, the report by the Auditor-General underlines the fact that there has been a mess, and it does say that at least there has been an attempt to fix up the mess. The findings of the report state:
. . . throughout the negotiations the Department and the Australian Government Solicitor sought to preserve the Commonwealth's position.

The reality is that the position that the Commonwealth, and particularly the Department, got itself into was a ludicrous one. The Auditor-General's report clearly outlines that ludicrous situation. The Auditor-General states:
The audit disclosed that the negotiations-
that is, for the building of the ship, Aurora Australis-
over the time charter for the vessel were affected by:
* the loss of negotiating power on the part of the Department following the public announcement of P& Polar as the successful tenderer and the issue of the letter of intent
* the lack of a firm time charter on which the short-listed companies could base their bids
* financial assumptions included in the P& Polar offer-
I mention that the assumptions did not prove to be correct-
* specification changes arising during the course of negotiations, and
* imprecise specifications for the scientific instrument system at the time of the tender.
I will not go into the mass of detail about the letter of intent, but I will mention the audit report's conclusions. The Auditor-General notes:
The P& Polar bid-
that is, the successful bid for Aurora Australia-

originally approved by the Government involved a first year higher cost of $10.1 million. As a result of negotiations over the vessel design and the charter details the Government agreed to an increase to $10.8 million per annum. In addition, payments totalling $895 425 were made to cover the additional costs associated with the scientific instrument system. There is also a potential payment of $400 000 per annum in lay-up costs following the first year's operations.
In addition-this is not mentioned by the Auditor-General-the ice pilot that will be required will also cost a large amount of money on top of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Another $28,000 per year. So there have been considerable increases to the cost since this P and O Polar bid was originally approved. The AuditorGeneral continues:

SPEECH.PARA: In the ANAO's view these increases were due to changes in specifications and the deletion of adverse financial conditions during the negotiation process. The ANAO considers that this negotiation process was made difficult because of assumptions included in the original P& Polar proposal which were not fully taken into account at the time of the Government's original consideration.
That means that the Department blundered. That is a very polite way for the Auditor-General to express it, but it means simply a costly departmental blunder. The Auditor-General goes on:
The need to issue the letter of intent and to issue letters of comfort on other matters arose from those assumptions.
These have proved to be not too soundly based. The Auditor-General continues:
The ANAO considers that throughout the negotiations the Department and the Australian Government Solicitor sought to preserve the Commonwealth's position.

The big question is whether or not the Commonwealth should ever have been put in a position where it had basically very little room to manoeuvre and very little power to negotiate, because it was locked into a deal which is now turning out to be a far more expensive deal. The Auditor-General states:
It is suggested that, in future cases of a similar nature, the Commonwealth's position would be strengthened if:
* proposals are based on a firm, approved time charter document
* the specifications are settled prior to any final decision and Government announcement, and
* the implications of any assumptions included in a proposal are explored and clarified before the Government's final consideration, decision and announcement.

In other words, those three points are exactly the opposite of the way the Government conducted itself in this matter. The Auditor-General is being remarkably polite in the manner in which he has couched this criticism. But it is overwhelming and damning criticism of monumental incompetence.

I suppose one could wonder why a department would conduct itself in this crazy way. Some people are prepared to offer suggestions. I do not know to what extent there are friendly relations between some of the people involved. I do not know whether or not there really are conflicts of interest but that matter was certainly raised at a Senate Estimates committee meeting. The potential for conflict of interest was certainly there. Perhaps Senator Calvert, who is in the chamber and who knows far more about this than I do, may wish to pursue that matter of the potential for conflict of interest. It is a matter of some concern, for example, that P and O did appear to have one of its subsidiaries, as I understand it, acting in this matter in a different form. The Auditor-General continues:
The approach taken by the Department was in part a result of the desire to have the vessel built and available for service as early as possible.

That is all very well. We have seen some very curious arrangements made when the desperation to get something ready quickly prompts governments into accepting deals which cost the taxpayer a fortune. I guess, as we look around this chamber, we can think of perhaps some elements of the building of this Parliament House that fall into that category. The Auditor-General continues:

The Department's view is that while additional costs were incurred, the Division has access to an improved vessel to that originally envisaged and that it has successfully negotiated to limit the impact of the financial conditions originally sought by P& Polar.

That is all very well but I do not know whether the Senate is aware of the fact that this super deluxe high quality ship which is costing us so much more has broken down basically on its voyage around the Antarctic continent. As Senator Calvert pointed out last week, it is now limping its way around the Antarctica, powered by its smaller No. 2 engine. Last Wednesday Senator Calvert asked the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) a question on this matter. I might say that the Minister promised to give the reply to Senator Calvert last Thursday. Today it still has not arrived. No doubt Senator Calvert will be pursuing that.

But the fact is that he asked for details as to the nature and cause of the mechanical problems which have delayed the Aurora Australis and the reasons why the vessel was not carrying a spare coupling between the main engine and the gear box, a procedure which is considered standard practice on such a vessel. During the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee C I asked specific questions about why the Aurora Australis had not been fitted with a skeg and ice knives to protect the propeller and rudder from ice. I was told that the Department had taken the considered view, as I recall it, that those things were not necessary because it had been assured on that, I understand, by P and O Polar. Last Wednesday Senator Calvert asked:
. . . is it not a fact that this problem-
which brought about the engine breakdown-

would have been averted if the Aurora Australis had been fitted with a skeg and ice knives to protect the propeller and rudder, a design feature which was recommended by some of P and O Polar's specialist technical advisers and apparently rejected by P and O and the Antarctic Division?

Senator Calvert then asked whether the Minister could give an assurance that the Aurora Australis would be modified to have these features with a view to protecting the safety of Australian expeditioners and the viability of our ongoing Antarctic research programs. I am concerned as to whether or not the Auditor-General was aware of what had happened-I presume he was not aware of what happened to the Aurora Australis in this break down because he signed his report on 2 November 1990 and Senator Calvert's question was asked on 7 November. It seems that the outcome in terms of the quality of the ship, let alone its cost, is unsatisfactory. I hope that we might get more direct and apposite answers to the questions we have been pursuing in Senate Estimates Committee hearings about the consistent capacity of the Antarctic Division to make major blunders. I regret that the Auditor-General feels that there ought to be an inquiry. I also regret that so many of the basic rules seem to have been avoided in the decision to accept the P and O Polar proposal. I hope that the Government will take notice of the Auditor-General's suggestions-those three points I read out earlier-which are the right way to go about things to save the Australian taxpayer money and to make certain that expeditioners are not put at risk by having to go to Antarctica in an unsatisfactory ship which at present is limping around that continent.

It is interesting to note that the contract eventually was signed in October 1988 after the vessel had been under construction for about 10 months. It was completed 11 months later.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know why P and O was given this particular job. It was because Carrington's were to build the ship at Newcastle and it just happened to be the time of a State election. That was the reason for the undue haste in the Minister putting out a press release saying that P and O Polar were to get the job before any contracts had been signed by the Government.

At present values, the accepted bid was $10.1m for the first season or $124m for 10 seasons but, as the Auditor-General points out in the report, as a result of the late signing of the charter, Australia is being asked to pay over $12m for the first full season or more than $150m for 10 seasons. Honourable senators will see that the delay in signing that charter has cost Australia about $25m. The Auditor-General is quite right in raising these matters.

In addition, we have all the add-on costs. The Commonwealth has to meet all the non-Antarctic season lay-up costs for the first time ever amounting to about half a million dollars a year. The lay-up port was not specified. The Commonwealth was required to pay an additional $460,000 for the provision of scientific equipment. The Commonwealth has to pay the charter rate for an 80-day Antarctic season whether it uses it or not. In answer to questions I asked at Estimates Committee hearings about the ice pilot, referred to by Senator Baume, there was a lot of doubt as to whether one would ever be needed. But the first time the ship goes to Antarctica, lo and behold an ice pilot is being used at a cost to the Commonwealth of about $28,000. I hope that does not have to happen again but there is a possibility it will.

During the negotiations, whilst it was set down in the tender documents that the captain of that particular ship had to have satisfied the specification of having four years Antarctic ice strategy experience, we now find on this first trip that the captain of that ship has nowhere near the experience required and that is why the ice pilot was required.

Another query that did not come up in the Auditor-General's report, which was a matter of great concern to me, was that during the construction of the ship no proper monitoring was done by technically qualified people. One of the officers used to take photos but there should have been much closer monitoring of the specific tender requirements in the construction of this ship. At the end of the day, once we are using the ship, there is always a possibility that things can go wrong. In fact, they have gone wrong.

I am looking forward with interest to see whether Senator Richardson, representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories tomorrow will tell me the reason for this incident. Any other ship that headed to Antarctica always carried a spare coupling that operates between the main engines. In this case it did not happen. I do not know whether that is because so much was spent on the ship that the company could not afford one. The upshot is that a ship is operating in the Antarctic with a smaller motor. Were that ship to get into difficulties, the members of the crew and members of our expedition could be placed at risk.

That is the reason that I and my colleagues have been raising so many questions about the haste with which this vessel was constructed, the anomalies in the tendering system and all the other shortcomings that have been pointed out and noted in a series of lengthy questions during the Estimates Committee hearings. Harking back to the cost of the ship-whilst I agree with Senator Richardson that the building of the ship in Australia by Australian workers was very advantageous, it is interesting to note that the bid by Reiber to build the ship was half the original bid of $124m.

Senator Baume raised the question of conflict of interest between some of the companies. I have been given an assurance by the heads of the Department that there is no conflict of interest. When the new charter for the appointment of a second vessel was granted, Anderson Hughes Australia, which is a subsidiary of P and O, won the tender. It just so happens that the providoring authority in Hobart for Antarctic ships is Beaufort Shipping Agency Co., which is also a subsidiary of P and O. We therefore have the trifecta of the ship being built and owned by P and O, the people tendering of the second ship being a subsidiary of P and O and the people providoring the ship being a subsidiary of P and O. The Department of Administrative Services has assured us in answer to questions at Estimates hearings that there is no conflict of interest between those companies, but the matter should never have arisen. However, there is now that suspicion.

I look forward with interest to scrutinising the criticism of the tendering process regarding the Aurora Australis by the Auditor-General. My colleagues and I will be pursuing these matters during the committee stage of the appropriations debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was concluding my contribution to this debate on Thursday evening when the debate was adjourned. At that time, I was discussing the start-up of the Australian Securities Commission and some of the matters I had raised in Estimates committees about that. I was using it as an example of how the Government goes about trying to solve problems and how sometimes it is ineffective.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment the Government's objective is to try to move the corporations regulatory environment to a system which works a lot better. In doing that, it followed through the advice of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its report of 1987, which raised concerns about how the cooperative scheme, which is in effect at the moment, was running. The new corporations legislation, which was passed through this Parliament in 1989, was to set up a national scheme, which, as honourable senators know, fell apart a little bit when earlier this year the High Court ruled that the Commonwealth did not have the power over incorporations of companies. Since then, on 29 June in Alice Springs, after some protracted negotiations, the States, in a heads of agreement document, agreed to refer their power over incorporations to the Commonwealth.

It is now five months since that time and the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 was introduced into the House of Representatives last Thursday. Unfortunately, after this gestation period of about three years, this Senate and this Parliament will have only a very short time in which to debate these amendments and the new national scheme. This is of some concern to me. The High Court case ensured that the Government rethink its approach to corporations legislation. It has certainly done that, with the cooperation of all the States. That is laudable.

One of the problems in setting up this new legislative framework is that all the State parliaments need to introduce applications of law legislation. With only a few sitting days remaining in most of the State parliaments and with this quite complex legislation-indeed, the legislation before the Federal Parliament is about the size of a telephone book-I wonder whether it is an appropriate way to go about changing the entire corporate affairs legislation in Australia if it can be debated in only such a short time by both the State parliaments and the Federal Parliament.

I reiterate that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the head of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Hartnell, are hell bent on setting up the Australian Securities Commission by 1 January. In my remarks before the adjournment on Thursday I drew the Senate's attention to the fact that in my home State of Western Australia and, I presume, in many other States none of the Corporate Affairs Commission staff have at this stage been offered jobs with the Australian Securities Commission. Indeed, a problem flowing from that is that none of the staff have been trained in using the complicated new computer system which will be used to make the Australian Securities Commission work.

If we are looking at having some continuity and having an effective corporate regulatory structure, we need staff that have had some experience in following the corporate players in their own States. It is a matter of alarm to me that the Australian Securities Commission does not seem to have made any progress since the meeting in Alice Springs at the end of June to deal with the staffing problems.

The other problem is that in Western Australia and, I believe, in many of the other States the Australian Securities Commission has decided on its head office locations. It has proceeded to lease premises but, at this time, no work has started on fitting out the offices. Certainly, that is the situation in Perth. There is about one acre of office space in the middle of Perth with no partitions, no furniture and no computers and we have only about 30 working days until Christmas, when the building industry closes down-and the building industry does not come back to work until the middle of January. I cannot see it in any way possible that these offices will be set up before 1 January.

The other matter is business compliance. I referred to it briefly prior to the adjournment on Thursday. One of the small matters is the necessity to issue each company in Australia with an eight-digit corporate identification number, or the `company's number', as it is referred to in the legislation. This is a necessity because, now that we are amalgamating the corporate affairs offices of all the States, obviously a number of companies will have similar or identical names. It has become necessary to give each company a number. It is probably a good idea and it is probably very sensible administration. The only trouble is that very few companies know about this idea and know that they are supposed to place this number on their documents. I referred to that on Thursday. To achieve a successful transition to this new national scheme, it is important that there be proper administration so that it is ready to operate properly on 1 January-as the Attorney-General would have us believe. We need a smooth transition to this scheme.

We also need the business community to be able to comply with it and to understand and support it. At this stage, most of the business community is in the dark about it. It is no wonder. Prior to 29 June in Alice Springs, and for the five months since then, the parliamentary draftsmen, solicitors-general from all the States and the Attorney-General's Department have been trying to come up with a package of legislation to put the scheme into effect, both in this Commonwealth Parliament and in all the States. I imagine that they have been far too busy to tell the poor old business people how they will make this work. I reiterate: it is important to have the administration right and for the business community to understand how the system will work. At this stage, we have neither of these prerequisites. As I have said on a number of occasions, there are only a few working days to Christmas. Personally, I cannot see how these two prerequisites will be achieved.

I have called on the Attorney-General and the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission to delay the start-up date until we are all satisfied that we will have a smooth transition to the new national scheme and that the original objective-back in 1987 the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs suggested that the old scheme be done away with-to have a more uniform and effective corporate regulatory environment is achieved.

As most honourable senators know, I have objections to the centralisation of this but I now believe that it is inevitable, unless the upper houses in some of the States knock back the legislation, so it is important that it be made to work. I see this headlong rush to set up the Australian Securities Commission by 1 January as something that will set the new scheme off to a very bad start and not actually achieve the objectives. So in terms of the Appropriation debate we will be quadrupling the money that the Federal Government spends on corporate regulation in Australia. But I suggest to the Senate, to the Attorney-General and to the people of Australia that the expenditure of this money will be wasted if we rush headlong into setting up the Australian Securities Commission before everybody is ready, and that is what seems to be taking place.

It has been brought to my attention today that the Government plans to introduce into the House of Representatives some 35 Bills to be debated during this week. The corporations legislation package is among those Bills. There are many important pieces of legislation amongst those packages and it strikes me, as a new senator in this place, that, if Parliament is supposed to scrutinise this legislation and government appropriations and, indeed, play some positive role in making sure that good quality legislation and administration come out of this place, introducing 35 Bills and hoping to have them dealt with in one week is certainly not a very good way of going about it.

It is my impression that the Senate should be having a very long look at even this corporate legislation amendment package-if not sending it to a committee to look at-to see that the draftsmen and the solicitors-general and the Attorney-General's Department have got it right. I cannot see how in five quick months of work they will have it right. I wish them luck.

The point I make is that the Senate and the Parliament need to look after the interests of the community. If we are to deal with these matters, if we are to look at the Appropriations, these matters need proper scrutiny. We should not be rushed into having an Australian Securities Commission set up by 1 January. We should be allowed to handle this and all of the other matters in good time and with the required amount of scrutiny, because I am sure that is what we are really here to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —In starting the debate on Estimates Committee B, I presume we are dealing with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade first. I do not intend to debate at length. Officers of the Department provided the Committee with the information sought to a level satisfactory to the Committee in most instances, but the Committee will note that a series of reservations have been entered by senators who wish particular matters to be pursued further in the Committee of the Whole. SPEECH.PARA: The first matter I wanted to raise arose not from the officers' answers but from some rather, if I may say with respect, evasive-certainly incomplete-answers from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to Australia's relationship with Taiwan and in almost all instances, I suggest, calls for further clarification. To save time I will run through this series of concerns and the Minister might be willing to respond to at least some of them a little more fully than he did during the Estimates hearing. I raised the difficulty of dealing with Taiwan without official contacts on matters that only an official within Taiwan could change. I was particularly interested in the question of wheat quotas and fresh fruit quotas because I was trying to explore how the Australian Government can progress Australia's interests in these matters if it is to have no contact with Taiwanese officials at all.

In relation to both wheat and fresh fruits, the Department has provided the answers the Minister was unable to provide in the Estimates. In the case of wheat the point is made that imports of Australian wheat have not been permitted by Taiwanese authorities since 1970-78. The information we are now given in this additional answer is that the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) has been making presentations at successive meetings of the Australia-Taiwan Trade Association and no doubt there has been other non-governmental negotiation. However, ultimately, it comes down to the attitude of the Government in Taiwan and in relation to that, Senator Evans-presumably it is Senator Evans-through this answer says that the Australian Government has given strong support to these efforts. The question, of course, is whether that is sufficient.

We know that the price for Australian wheat has dropped this year, in part because of a good crop elsewhere in the world, and Australian wheat growers are looking for every opportunity to export their product, which is internationally accepted as being a high quality product. Yet it seems that because of the way in which this Government does business in Taiwan there is no direct role it is prepared to assume to try to negotiate a market-a market from which Australia has been excluded since 1970-78. I therefore ask the Minister: What does he mean when he says the Government has given strong support to those efforts? Is there no way in which the Government can, through direct contact, and therefore hopefully more effective contact, seek to open up that market to Australian producers?

A similar position exists in relation to fresh fruit. We see now from the answer to this question, which has come in since the Estimates Committee, a small allocation to Australia of some fresh fruits. Fifty-seven tonnes of apples have been allowed in 1990, which I guess is a leg into the market, but it is really only a minute introduction. The question is: Again what can the Australian Government do? Does it simply throw its hands up in the air and say, `Because there are no official contacts we can have no trade contacts with those who claim to be the Administration within Taiwan; therefore, we can do nothing to further the interests of Australian producers in this regard'. From this answer we note that in March 1989 Taiwan announced that it would consider applications for the import of a number of other fruits, and this answer helpfully points out that that would be relevant to Australia in the areas of honeydew melon, watermelon, peaches, nuts, citrus and fruits. The question is, however, how the Australian Government can further the producers' interests if it is not prepared to speak to the decision makers on this aspect? Again this issue has tended to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —What page of Hansard are you referring to?

—I am referring to the answers to supplementary questions, which I do not think are numbered. The copy I got is not numbered, but I understand a covered copy was delivered to my office this morning. I have to refer to that which was delivered earlier. It relates to Hansard page 16. That answer said that the Government supports strongly the elimination of all barriers. That avoids the question of how the Government will contribute to the elimination of these barriers which are hindering our access-in some cases introduction-to this rapidly growing market of an ever increasingly more affluent people. How will the Government improve this market if it is not prepared to enter into any direct negotiations on an important trade matter?

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister is aware, shortcomings in the immigration procedures have hindered Australia's economic opportunities in Taiwan. The Minister is probably aware that the time it takes to grant student visas is still longer than that of our competitors and although the processes involved have improved, it is still a time consuming matter. In a very competitive world we cannot afford these extra barriers; therefore I asked whether it was true that two immigration officers were being put in. The answer from the Minister, as I read it, was that some further resources were being made available.

Now that the Minister has had time to reflect on the matter, I ask him again whether it is in fact the case that two immigration officers, clearly not acting in an official capacity and therefore in Taiwan on ordinary passports-I accept that-or two immigration officers on leave, or placed by some other method, are going to be placed in the Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) office in Taipei. If they are, I would be very pleased to hear that. I would still be critical of the fact that visas must be issued in Hong Kong although the details are taken in Taipei, which seems to be clumsy in this day and age. It would, nevertheless, be some improvement and perhaps the Minister can tell the chamber whether that is the case.

The next issue I wanted to raise was that of a Foreign Affairs officer being put in the office in Taipei. I do not think the Minister need be shy about this matter. We have been urging for some time that the Government would do better if it had better political advice coming out of Taipei. Again, I accept that, if an officer of the Department was to be put there, it might be necessary for that officer to take leave or assume some unofficial status, but that does not worry me as much as whether the Australian Government is getting good information. I am led to believe that, notwithstanding the Minister really evading the question, an officer of the Department has taken leave and will be put in Taipei. If that is the case, I would like the Minister to inform the chamber today, and we will be the first to welcome that move in a positive direction.

I would also like to raise the issue of the ongoing sorry saga of the direct commercial air links. Mr Chairman, you would be aware that for years now-all the time this Government has been in office-at irregular intervals the Minister concerned, now Senator Evans, has come into this chamber and said, `Progress is being made; we are hopeful; we trust that we soon will have that direct air link'. We still do not have that direct air link. The last information we have had from this Government is consistent with what we have heard over the years, that is, `positive progress is being made; hope to make it; announcement of a successful completion of the project in the near future'.

The best information that I have been able to get to the contrary is that there are still major hurdles in the way of that link which this Government is trying to develop involving a subsidiary of Qantas to avoid the flag carrier issue. But it is extremely frustrating for Australian business when, for example, they are competing with other Asian business people. They see Singapore Airlines Ltd flying into Taipei, as do Thai Airways International Ltd, Japan Air Lines, and Asian airlines. They also see Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd flying in, which is the greatest embarrassment of all because Cathay Pacific is partly owned by the People's Republic of China. From Europe they see KLM Royal Dutch Airlines flying in. From America-which competes with us in a number of these markets and which I could have mentioned under the previous discussion of wheat-three airlines fly to Taipei: United Airlines; what was North-West Orient flies in-I think it has now got a different name; and Delta Airlines fly direct from the United States to Taipei.

Australian businessmen are trying to compete in this market, particularly selling lighter and higher value-added goods, and having to compete with these direct air routes. Australian producers, of course, have got to tranship through Singapore and through Hong Kong where, as I indicated a moment ago, they are likely to tranship to Cathay Pacific, partly owned by the People's Republic of China, for on-passage to Taipei, because the Australian Government has accepted the requirement of Beijing that an Australian national airline is not to land in Taipei.

At a time when Australia is in such a parlous economic state and we are all presumably looking at ways in which we can expand Australia's economic opportunity, this additional hurdle, this additional frustration that is having to be experienced by Australian business people, is just one too many. I raised with Senator Evans in the Estimates this question: If the Australian Government is not going to be able to complete its chosen path, that is, using the subsidiary of Qantas, why not become more active in encouraging the alternative options that are about?

The Australian World Airways option is being promoted by a group from Melbourne who, I am led to believe, have run into nothing but hurdles from this Government because, of course, it might intrude upon its chosen path. If the Qantas subsidiary is not going to work, why not encourage Australian World Airways to get into the market? Being a non-government body, it overcomes one little difficulty. Perhaps it might have a greater opportunity of completing a deal that would benefit Australia's business.

As the Minister knows, even if that is not successful, there is also the very large Evergreen transport organisation, which I think is based in Taiwan and is one of the largest transport organisations in the world. It is looking to try to develop the option of direct air links between Taipei and Beijing, but it is also interested in developing direct air links between Taiwan and Australia. If we are not going to be able to achieve the Qantas objective, then perhaps it should be encouraged. In other words, it is no good that we be continually told that progress is being made when it is not being made. The Government will be doing better if it gives some of these other alternatives an opportunity to work.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite indebted to Senator Hill for raising the whole question of Australia's relations with Taiwan because, as it happens, today I put out a full press statement, which I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, recording the results of a full scale review of Australia's relations with Taiwan which has been in preparation for some time and which was the subject of consideration by Cabinet today, and the results of which are now on the public record. Apparently that has been overlooked by Senator Hill.
—When did you put the statement out?
—About half an hour ago. You are supposed to be quick on your feet.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN POLICY TOWARDS TAIWAN

The Australian Government today completed a review on Australia's policy towards Taiwan. The review covered developments since December 1986, when the Government had last conducted an in-depth survey of Australian policy towards Taiwan.

Cabinet agreed that there was no basis for variation of our basic ``One China'' policy, to which all Australian governments Labor and Coalition alike have adhered since 1972. Under this policy, we continue to recognise the PRC as the sole legal Government of China and acknowledge its claim that Taiwan is a province of China.

However, within this framework, Australia has been able to develop a healthy commercial relationship with Taiwan. We want this to continue to expand. Since we took office in 1983, two-way trade has tripled, and is now worth $3.8 billion per year. Taiwan has consistently been one of Australia's most important trading partners, ranking fifth in 1989. In that year, Australia was Taiwan's largest supplier of aluminium, wool, iron ore, beef and barley, and its second largest supplier of coal and zinc. This reflects not only the efforts of our business community, but also the solid backing which this Government has provided.
The following measures have been taken by the Government since 1986 to encourage Australia/Taiwan trade and investment:

establishment of the Taiwan Market Service (TMS) in Australia, complementing the Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) operated by the Australian Chamber of Commerce, enabling both offices to operate a fully professional commercial advisory and assistance service for Australian business and government clients;
active support for the setting up of a visa facilitation service in ACIO, which enables Taiwan residents to visit Australia with the minimum of fuss and delay;
facilitation of the establishment of an Australian Education Centre in Taipei, to promote the sale of Australian education services to Taiwan;
passage of legislation, which has the effect of removing all doubt about the security of Taiwan investments in Australia;
encouragement of visits by Taiwan business representatives to Australia, encouraging them to strengthen trade and investment links between Australia and Taiwan;
promotion of business migration, leading Taiwan to become our second largest source of business migrants;
continued extension of Developing Country Preferences to Taiwan, which is currently the largest beneficiary of the scheme;
support for the participation by Taiwan, together with the PRC and Hong Kong, in the process of Asia/Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC);
active encouragement of Australia Asia Airlines, a fully owned subsidiary of Qantas, in its negotiations with Taiwan aviation interests to operate a direct Australia/Taiwan air service; and
vigorous pursuit, through all means at its disposal, of trade and technical issues such as market access for beef, wheat and fresh fruit.

The review has resulted in the Government both reaffirming its approach to Taiwan and agreeing to provide even more active support for the development of the commercial relationship. It was specifically agreed today that the Government would:
support the further strengthening, both numerically and in terms of professional level, of the ACIO and Taiwan commercial offices in Australia;
allow Taiwan to operate a visa facilitation service in Australia to a level commensurate with that offered in Taiwan by ACIO;
investigate ways in which any double taxation problems with Taiwan might be overcome;
appoint a prominent Taiwan business representative to the Advisory Board of the Multi-Function Polis (MFP); and
give further consideration to the expansion of Taiwan's commercial representation in Australia.

The Government also reaffirmed today the importance of reaching early agreement on the establishment of a direct airlink between Australia and Taiwan, and emphasized that it would continue to support the efforts of commercial negotiators to secure a workable arrangement.

Overall, this Government has consistently taken a measured and realistic attitude to the management of Australia's relations with Taiwan. Together with the private sector, we have worked energetically to develop a vigorous commercial relationship with Taiwan, whilst fulfilling our responsibilities to the PRC.
We remain committed to this pragmatic and responsible approach, which has served, and will continue to serve, Australia's interests well.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be interesting to know whether you have sent it to my office.

—The way the honourable senator carries on, he does not always justify that sort of favourable treatment, but never mind. I am delighted to give him a spare copy on this occasion. A number of the specific matters that Senator Hill has raised are addressed in that statement, although necessarily it cannot be perhaps as explicit as one might like on some particular matters of detail. Let me address some of the questions of detail that he has drawn our attention to today.

SPEECH.PARA: First, he raised the question of agricultural trade discussions and in particular in relation to wheat, making the point that there were difficulties in the conduct of that trade if contacts are not able to be made at government to government level. I acknowledge the fact that there can be difficulties if contact is impossible on a governmental basis. Nonetheless, it has proved possible over the years with Australia, as with most other countries with substantial trading relationships with Taiwan, to have unofficial contacts-unofficial, technical, informal contacts. It is the case that quite recently in the United States such contacts took place with a series of informal talks. Participants on the Australian side included meat and wheat industry representatives, the head of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) in Taipei, which is part of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, and officials with trade responsibilities. The Taiwanese participants included representatives from trade, agricultural and economic agencies.

The practice of holding such informal meetings to discuss trade and commercial matters is well established and is one pursued by Australia and other countries which have diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China (PRC). In these and previous such unofficial discussions which have taken place in Australia and elsewhere, Australia and Taiwan have addressed a range of commercial and technical questions, including access problems facing Australian exporters of beef, wheat and fresh fruit in the Taiwan market, as well as quarantine, taxation and customs issues. I make it very clear that such talks do not signify any change to Australia's longstanding one-China policy under which we recognise the PRC as the sole legal Government of China, acknowledge China's claim that Taiwan is a province of China, and refrain from official dealings with the Taiwan authorities.

Nonetheless, what I have just said gives substance to the statement to which Senator Hill referred in the answer that he was given, to the effect that `the Government has given strong support to these efforts'. We have been giving strong support and the unofficial talks to which I have referred are one such vehicle through which that support has been made manifest.

As for visa questions to which Senator Hill drew attention, he will have noticed that one aspect of that statement today-I am afraid that I have just given him my only remaining copy-is a reference to the Taiwanese office in Australia being given the capacity to engage in visa facilitation processes to the same extent that ACIO does in Taiwan. I believe that that will be of some assistance in smoothing the path for these visit arrangements. There can be no question of direct issuing of visas by the respective offices in question, because that is a consular act of a kind that raises questions of incompatibility with the one-China policy which I have just described.

As to the question of resources in the respective offices, as today's statement makes clear, we have understood the argument of the business communities in both countries that both the level and strength of occupancy of those respective offices needs to be upgraded, and we support that view. The situation is that Australia's trade and economic interests in Taiwan are represented not by the Government but through the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei, which is operated, as I said earlier, by the Australian Chamber of Commerce, a non-government organisation based in Canberra. As such it is simply not the case that Australian Government officials in any capacity are posted to Taiwan. It is quite inappropriate for Senator Hill to seek a response from me in terms of officers of Foreign Affairs or officers of Immigration. The truth of the matter is that Australian Government officials as such are not posted to Taiwan. I am not in a position to give Senator Hill an answer in the terms in which he seeks it.

It is the case that the ACIO is staffed by a number of Australian-based personnel. It is also my understanding that ACIO has made a decision to appoint additional Australian-based staff in Taipei to upgrade in particular the visa facilitation service that is currently being offered, particularly by developing a computerised visa issue system linked with the Australian Consulate-General in Hong Kong, which computerised arrangement already exists in a number of other countries. It may also prove possible for ACIO to appoint further people on its staff with particular responsibilities in terms of policy liaison with the Taiwanese authorities. But that is a matter for ACIO and not for the Australian Government. I am afraid that I cannot answer those questions further as a result. In regard to the question of air links, again one needs to state at the outset that Australia's acceptance of the PRC as the sole legal Government of China, which I understand still to be the position of the Opposition, even though some competing signals are given from time to time--

TALK.START.PARA: —Given by whom?
—In terms of expressing a willingness on the part of Dr Hewson to visit Taiwan, I hope not in any official capacity, because to do so would be incompatible with that recognition of the one China.
—Do you object to his visit to Taiwan?
—It is a matter for judgment as to whether he should or not.
—In an unofficial capacity.
—If it is possible for the Leader of the Opposition to visit anywhere in an unofficial capacity. It is certainly not very easy for a Minister to do so.
—It is all right for your government officials to do it, provided that they have an ordinary passport-including officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

—I make the point that, although here as elsewhere the Opposition wants to have things both ways, our acceptance, and I hope the Opposition's acceptance, of the PRC as the sole legal Government of China, and our respective acknowledgment of Taiwan as a province of China, means that no Australian Government can conclude a government to government air service agreement with Taiwan; nor could a flag carrier such as Qantas Airways Ltd or Taiwan's China Airlines operate a direct Australia-Taiwan service. Such a service could be established only on the basis of a commercial arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the case that Australia Asia Airlines (AAA) has been negotiating with Taiwan interests for some time. I can certainly appreciate the frustration that the delay in setting up that air link may be causing. I share some of that sense of frustration myself because I readily acknowledge the utility of an air link in terms of a further rapid expansion of the Australia-Taiwan economic relationship.

I reject completely any assertion or suggestion or implication that the Government is responsible for the delay. The fact is that the commercial negotiations in question have proven protracted, difficult and very sensitive. When the Government receives a proposal from AAA or any other commercial interest-and I stress any other commercial interest-we will consider it on its merits. I cannot anticipate the nature of that consideration. We would certainly be interested in any proposal that is consistent with our obligations and our commitments under our one-China policy. We hope that agreement can be reached on workable arrangements in the near future. Those negotiations involving AAA are certainly continuing- continuing, I believe, as we speak today. I certainly hope that the remaining difficulties can be identified and ironed out.

The situation regarding other airlines flying into Taiwan was made the subject of a final comment from Senator Hill. I would like to put the situation concerning other countries and other airlines squarely on the record, because I think there is a lot of misapprehension and confusion about this.

To our knowledge carriers from 12 countries plus Hong Kong currently fly to Taiwan. Taiwan's flag carrier, China Airlines, flies to 10 countries plus Hong Kong. Three of the countries which have air links with Taiwan, namely Brunei, South Africa and Korea, do not have diplomatic relations with the PRC, so obviously no question of sensitivity or difficulty arises there. Singapore has an air link with Taiwan. This will continue now that diplomatic relations with the PRC have been established. This predates the establishment of those relations. All but one of the others-and this is the important point-established services prior to their governments' recognition of the PRC.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about KLM?

—I said all but one. I am getting to that, if Senator Hill will curb his racing hormones. The exception is the Netherlands. Its establishment of an air link with Taiwan was, however, the cause of quite significant problems in the PRC-Netherlands bilateral relationship. The truth of the matter is that the bilateral relationship was nothing like as substantial between the Netherlands and the PRC as is Australia's. We have to take into account, rather than clumsily blustering into these things in the way Senator Hill and the Opposition might be minded to, the implications of acting in clear breach of understandings and commitments which have been entered into on a bilateral basis with the PRC.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other case to date of an air link being established with Taiwan by a country recognising the PRC was that of Egypt, which in 1989 permitted a service by China Airlines that operated for a few months but was then suspended, I understand following some rather forceful representations to Egypt on this subject.

I would say finally in this respect that there are a number of countries in a position similar to Australia's which are also working to establish air links with Taiwan within the framework of their respective one China policies. They include the United Kingdom, France, Austria, Canada and New Zealand. Obviously we are monitoring very closely developments in the negotiations involving these other countries and we hope very much that it will be possible to announce a breakthrough quite soon.

It is really difficult to find much in this press release that today will give heart to those who see economic opportunities wanting because of the Australian Government's very shy and overcautious approach in relation to commercial activities in Taiwan.

I think it is just one of those classic examples where it does not affect Australia's interests at all except to give Australian business people easier access to a body that can help facilitate their trading development. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

SPEECH.PARA: So, Senator Bishop, you can curb your waspish tongue. TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps when the Minister is acquiring that information, his officers could pay attention to an internal audit of 11 April 1990. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some reservations about that part of the report to the chamber of Estimates Committee B which deals with the bilateral relations and human rights in China, the Commonwealth Secretariat and the international conventions. If the Minister has any officials waiting here to advise on international conventions, I advise that I will not be pursuing that matter so the officials can go.
—I am sorry, there is no official here to deal with that.

—Then I go to bilateral relations, referenced in program 3.2. I draw the attention of the Minister to matters which arise out of the responses given to questions at Estimates Committee hearings and, more particularly, to questions that have been placed on notice. I refer the Minister to the questions that I asked him about respect for basic human rights and freedoms. Budget-related Paper No. 6.8 cites a performance indicator for the globals issue area of the appropriations being sought as being `advances in the promotion and protection of fundamental human rights'. Today, I want to find out just where the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is at in its monitoring of human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The example that I gave was China. I asked the Minister what was happening to human rights in China in the population control area and in the workers' rights area. I asked the Minister whether these workers' rights had been violated. Had there been a tightening up of controls by the Chinese authorities over workers and workers' associations since the Tiananmen Square massacre? The response that the Minister has given indicates that there has been a tightening up and that there have been violations of the rights to assembly and the rights of association and that the Government has expressed concern about these. It says that in the last year new laws have been passed in China restricting rights of assembly in Beijing and Guangdong. Freedom of association has been further curtailed by the policies enacted on 31 January 1990 calling for intensified politicisation of associations already dominated by the Chinese Communist Party. These laws apply to all Chinese citizens, including workers. Martial law decree No. 10 of 12 June 1989 declared illegal the Beijing workers' autonomous federation, which had been formed in May 1989.

Here we have a regression by China into policies which violate human rights and specifically workers' rights in contradistinction to what is happening in most other parts of the world, including most other parts of the communist world. The Minister's response goes on:

Other workers' organisations have been declared illegal although we do not hold specific details. On 14 November 1989 the governing body, the ILO, adopted a complaint alleging violations of workers' rights.

I go to this question of workers' rights being violated and workers' conditions and payments being undermined because workers, as human beings, are attempting to exercise their fundamental human rights. I go to a question that I asked as recorded on page B9 which reads:

Has the Department specifically raised with the Chinese authorities its concerns about the new local regulations in Shanghai-a very substantial area-which are operative from 1 August 1990 regarding family planning and birth control policy in that area and which involve inherently the violation of human rights and workers' rights?
I asked:
Is the Department aware of the specific regulations which do include violations of human rights and workers' rights, specifically?

The answer that was given to me did not relate to Shanghai at all; it related to Hunan family planning rules and regulations approved by the Henan province-I think that is how it should read rather than Heran-authorities on 12 April 1990 to come into force on 1 July 1990. It said that the regulations in question laid down strict family planning guidelines and imposed a system of economic penalties for non-compliance with these guidelines.
The response from the Minister was that the Government had not raised this matter with the Chinese Government. It went on:

I agree that the imposition of punitive measures in the area of family planning is a matter of some concern as it raises questions of the rights of individuals versus the economic imperatives of the state.

This does not really answer my question. I want an answer to my question about the new local regulations in Shanghai. Is the Department aware of those? As a backbencher, I am aware of them, but is the Department aware of them? Has the Minister been properly advised? Does he have the information? Will he insist that the Department get the information relating to human rights violations in this area?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am entirely familiar with Senator Harradine's concerns for the situation of human rights in China. Of course, I share many of those concerns, not least so far as the rights of assembly and association and the pursuit of traditional rights by workers and their organisations are concerned. I continue to share his indignation that there has been a significant deterioration in that respect over time.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as human rights associated with the family planning programs are concerned, I am as puzzled as Senator Harradine is by the reference to Henan or Heran province, particularly since, whatever else it is, it is not Shanghai, which is what the question was about. All I can say is that I am in the process of getting some further information in this respect. I want to give Senator Harradine, as I promised I would, a considered review of what exactly we know or can find out about the way in which these particular programs are operating in Shanghai and the vicinity or indeed elsewhere that information comes to our hand.

I do take seriously the point that I have often made in these hearings that, whatever might be my enthusiasm for family planning in general and in terms of poverty alleviation and development assistance, I certainly do not think that should be conducted on a coercive basis and in a way that interferes with other rights of the people in question. If there was foundation for the suggestion that coercion was being used in these programs I would have a number of concerns. As I have discussed with Senator Harradine before, most of the time there is a difficulty in drawing a line between coercion and incentive at the margin. It may be that there is room for some differences of interpretation in that respect. To the extent that there is a question of coercion of some kind going on, that raises the human rights problems, and ones about which I would be very concerned.

We are in the middle of following this up. Unfortunately, the time constraints have just not made it possible to complete this in time for this debate today. I propose writing to Senator Harradine in some detail reviewing this material when I and my Department and the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau are in a position to formulate a full and considered response, which is what he has now sought for a long time and what I think is owing to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). I will look forward to that. One of the reasons I focused on Shanghai is that it is the Shanghai medical electronic equipment factory that is purchasing the ultrasound machines that are being supplied, partly through Australian taxpayers' money through the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) aid and the development import finance facility (DIFF) program, to the extent of roughly $2.5m. The Shanghai medical electronic equipment company is actually purchasing those ultrasound machines.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that those machines will be used by the State Family Planning Commission. The other fact is that the Shanghai regulations, as reported by the Shanghai daily newspapers on 31 July 1990, set forth quite draconian punishments to be meted out to persons not complying with the requirements of the State Family Planning Commission which is receiving these machines from Australia. That is one of the reasons that I focused on the Shanghai regulations. One of the disciplinary measures to be meted out is, for a couple who have had a second child, a fine amounting to three times their combined average income as measured by their incomes two years before the second child. Those couples having a third child or further children would be subject to fines amounting to four times their measured annual income. Again, that is a violation of workers' rights in the exercising of their basic human rights which, incidentally, are outlined in a letter of 16 February from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade relating to the plan of action which was adopted at Mexico City:
. . . respect for human life is basic to all human societies; and that all couples and individuals have the basic right to decide freely and responsibly the number and spacing of their children . . .

If that is to be followed through, clearly it is a violation of the rights of workers who are exercising that particular right. Furthermore, under the Shanghai regulations work units with unplanned births would not be eligible for selection as enlightened work units and would also be subject to fines. Of course, there is no shop steward in those areas because there are no unions. It is a gross violation of human rights and I will be very grateful if the Minister and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will pursue those matters very vigorously and continue to monitor those questions.
I turn now to the answer that was given to me in respect of program 5.2, the environment assistance program. In the Estimates Committee I quoted that the Government had indicated:

As part of the four-year Environmental Assistance Program which commenced last year, activities focused on forestry, sustainable agriculture and population stabilisation will be undertaken in 1990-91 at both regional and country levels.

I asked a number of questions, including how this was to be put into practice. The response that I have received has not dealt with how this will be put into practice. I would like that question to be taken on notice and for an answer to be given to me at some stage. It is a matter of getting some clarification about that question. I apologise to the Committee of the Whole for having to raise this, but these were questions on notice to which I received responses and I have not had the opportunity in the Estimates Committee hearings to follow through the responses.

In a similar vein, I ask whether the Minister could provide further details at some stage in respect of the International Development Association projects in India about which there have been some responses, but I need to have more detailed responses in respect of the project that is at points 3 and 4 in the Department's responses to me.

In respect of the DIFF program, I want to follow up the points that were made concerning the supply of ultrasound machines to the State Family Planning Commission. This matter was raised initially at the Estimates Committee hearing by Senator Olsen. For the information of honourable senators who were not at the Estimates Committee hearing, I point out that the Government through a DIFF project has put forward, I think, $1.4m of DIFF money and $1.2m of aid money for the supply of what we had thought was 200 ultrasound machines to the State Family Planning Commission and what I now believe will be 100 such machines to the Commission in order to assist its population control program. I am not satisfied at all with the responses that have come forward, given the fact that the China program is a coercive program.

We have heard the Minister say today that at last the Department and the Minister will address themselves to the questions of violations of human rights that I have been raising for the last two years. It is quite obvious that the Department has not had the material on which to make a proper assessment as to whether these machines will be used for coercive purposes. It is quite clear from the responses that have been given to me that there has been an attempt to sidetrack the issue because the Department ascertained that the machines would probably not be used for the purposes of sex-related abortions. It will never be in a position to say whether or not that will be the fact. I do not know from whom it obtained that undertaking or whether the undertaking is worth anything, in any event.

What we do have is clear evidence that there is a requirement in certain areas of China for women who have had one child to be compulsorily fitted with an interuterine device (IUD). There have been statements clearly made by experts in the field that many of those women are required, from time to time, to be subjected to X-rays to see whether they retain the IUD.

I would like to refer to the Sunday Herald of 16 September 1990 when this issue was reported following the meeting of the Estimates Committee that was held here in Canberra. Under a headline `Abortion row over exports to China' by Martin Daly, the national correspondent in Canberra, it says:
Australia may be supporting China's ruthless population control program by supplying medical equipment that could be used to force abortions.

The equipment can be used to detect twin pregnancies, determine whether women have removed contraceptive devices under China's one child per family policy or to determine the sex of a foetus, potentially allowing female babies to be aborted.
Of course, the Government did address itself to that latter question. The article, presumably quoting the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, says:

AIDAB claims it has been given a policy statement by China's State Family Planning Commission (SFPC). The agency claims the SFPC was not part of the abortion process and had a strong policy against discrimination against girls.
However, that's a line dismissed by another China expert, Steven Mosher, director of Asian Studies at the Californian Claremont Institute. ``That's simply not true,'' he said.

``Because of the one-child policy and the status of having male children, Chinese women often manufacture a history of illness so they can be examined on ultrasound. But the real reason is so they can kill the child if it is female,'' he said.

That is the sort of pressure that is being applied. I understand that the Minister has said that, at last, he is going to subject these matters to some scrutiny. The sort of pressure that is being placed on the women, in particular, in China is something which we should not be in any way associated with. I feel it is high time that the sorts of statements that have been emanating from the Minister-presumably written by AIDAB-have to be closely examined because they do not stand up to the light of day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only to say that I will follow up the specific matters that Senator Harradine has indicated he wants further information on-particular projects, particular places and so on. It is obviously not possible to give him further information about that today.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of the ultrasound equipment, as I said in the Committee hearing itself, there are of course entirely legitimate clinical uses for such equipment in antenatal care, and it is not to be assumed that the direction of that equipment is as Senator Harradine has expressed his concern.

I repeat my undertaking to him that we will look very carefully at the material on this. There is quite a lot of material; a lot of it has been a bit slow to get hold of in terms of understanding precisely what the legal framework is that is presently operating in the relevant parts of China. As soon as humanly possible, I will get something to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise the question of the industrial relations difficulties within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which were raised in the Estimates Committee. Although the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to some extent wanted to pass off the responsibility to the Department of Industrial Relations, we were informed, as I recall it, that the matters were basically under control and that the work bans had been lifted because allowances were being reconsidered in the light of further charges that the Department wished to place upon officers serving abroad. SPEECH.PARA: I now understand that the work bans are back on at overseas embassies. Obviously, the business of the Government is suffering but, in some ways, I think what is more important is that the international standing of Australia is not well served when industrial relations disputes are being publicly pursued or industrial bans are being pursued in our overseas missions.

I might say that earlier in the year when this was brought to my attention I thought that officers in the Department had a good case and had been poorly served by the administrative procedures, which the Minister, as I said, passed off as the fault of another Department. I would really like to take this opportunity to find out what has gone wrong again and what this Minister is doing to overcome the problems that are being experienced in this regard in his Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not only officers in my Department that are affected by the overseas living allowance and rent and utilities contribution issue which has given rise to industrial difficulties. There are some 2,500 people overseas altogether, of which my Department represents about 1,000. Nonetheless, we are obviously pretty central to this issue. Because of the way in which it was dragging on, I did in recent times take a strong personal interest in this and engaged in a quite protracted process of negotiation myself with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), in association with our respective departments, which have been working on this.

SPEECH.PARA: We came up with a package which, in the judgment of the three Ministers-and I readily express my support for it-was a fair and balanced one. It was not as generous as ideally I would like to have been able to provide for my officers overseas, who have, I think, been slipping behind in terms of their capacity to handle those situations financially. Nonetheless, given all the other constraints that are operating on Government, I think it is a fair package and one that did represent for most people a net advance or, in any event, a significant improvement in their conditions.

That particular package as negotiated was communicated to our officers, with results that are still not yet totally clear in terms of the nature of their reaction. But of the 32 posts of the 90 posts altogether that we have overseas which have replied to requests for reaction to the package, 14 have expressly indicated their acceptance of it. I think it is a reasonable assumption that a number of those posts which have not been explicit about it have allowed their silence, as it were, to speak for them.

The Government has made it very clear that there is no further scope for negotiation. This does not represent just some kind of offer from the Government that is now on the table; it represents a concluded decision of the Government as to what we are prepared to pay, and if there is any further resistance to it that is protracted then that offer will be withdrawn and the public servants in question will just have to take their chances through the arbitral process.

It is management's judgment that the position as reached in the way that I have described is broadly acceptable to the overwhelming majority of the officers concerned. However, it has not proved to date to be acceptable, it seems, to the leadership of the Public Service Union. It is on that basis that a campaign is still being waged and bans of a kind have been reimposed.

This is a manifestly unsatisfactory situation. It is one that the Minister for Industrial Relations is now addressing directly. We are making it very clear in further circulars and so on that are going out to everyone what the precise nature of the offer is-its non-negotiable character. Unless it is accepted, people can expect to find themselves considerably worse off.

We do not want to be too ham-fisted about this. There is a real sense of grievance around, some of which I think is legitimate in terms of the past situation. People in those posts are working under very difficult conditions and I think they deserve our sympathy and respect. But equally there is no justification for putting Australia's interests at risk by insufficient servicing of visitors passing through or some of the other sorts of things that can be involved in these work bans.

I simply express the hope that cooler heads will prevail sooner rather than later and that this issue will rapidly be brought to a conclusion. I think that brings the Committee reasonably up to date on what the situation is, without going into endless details about tables and the details of the operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of small matters that I would like to get out of the way and it might be convenient to deal with them in a group.
