TALK.START.PARA: -Before going to the answers to the questions on notice that were given to me by the Minister relating to the new amount that was set aside for the environment, I want to raise with the Minister the whole question of development aid education and point out to him, as he probably knows, that the Australian Development International Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) survey seemed to indicate that there was a lessening of support in Australia for overseas development assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a disconcerting feature and it is even more disconcerting that apparently that has been reflected in the overseas development assistance budget this year, which appears to represent an effective cut of $96m over last year. Some of the areas cut include an 11 per cent cut in funds for international agricultural research, which is absolutely vital and was recognised as such by AIDAB in response to questions I asked. Here we have an 11 per cent cut in funds for this most worthy and important tool for overcoming poverty in various parts of the world. There is a substantial cut in funds which have been going to a number of programs, including programs relating to reafforestation and the food for work program in Ethiopia; substantial cuts have been made to the funding going to the sub-Saharan region and so on. The list is quite enormous and I think Senator Teague-I notice him in the chamber-referred to the cuts which have resulted in the Overseas Service Bureau (OSB) having to postpone sending a number of volunteers overseas. I think it was 50, was it not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, a whole departure group.

—That came about because of cuts to the funding for overseas development assistance in the Budget. That is most disconcerting and what concerns me is that while those things have been cut, the international population controllers have been able to get their hands on more money from this Government. The United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) and the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) have had their funding increased by this Government through the back door. As is evident in the material provided to me by AIDAB in respect of the new environmental assistance program, both those organisations are going to get a substantial whack of that money.

SPEECH.PARA: Those organisations are going to get, I think, 35 per cent of the money earmarked for the new environmental assistance program. One must question why. On the one hand the Government is cutting millions of dollars from a program focusing on reafforestation, while on the other hand it is increasing the sums available to UNFPA by 44 per cent and to IPPF by 100 per cent. I challenge the Government that that is quite an improper thing to do. In my view, even to assist those organisations is a misuse of taxpayers' money. The United States of America refuses to provide any money to UNFPA. I quote Peter McPherson, the administrator of the US Agency for International Development who said:
UNFPA participates in the management of a program of coercive abortion and involuntary sterilisation in the People's Republic of China, within the meaning of the Kemp/Kaston Amendment.

When I talk about China, I am also talking about Tibet. On 29 March 1990 an article entitled, `Genocide through Abortion' appeared in the Advocate in Melbourne. It was written by Wendy Miller and stated:

China is trying to wipe out the Tibetan race through forced abortion and sterilisation programs, and its population transfer policy, said the Vice President of the Tibetan Women's Association in Exile, Ms Pema Dechem today.
The US Government refuses to fund UNFPA because it participates in the management of a program of coercive abortion and involuntary sterilisation, according to Mr McPherson.

Three days after the massacre in Tiananmen Square UNFPA voted $US57m to the China coercive population control program, supported by the Australian Government representative at that conference. That action was opposed by the US representative who attended the conference. If honourable senators want official statements, there are reams of official statements made by UNFPA officials about the China program. UNFPA officials have had a number of things to say. Let me give the chamber a couple of examples: Manfred Kulessa, China representative of UNFPA, in an article entitled `UN official praises China population control program' in the Xinhua General Overseas News Service, Beijing. The article was dated 11 July 1987, and stated:

It is significant that here in China . . . the government has shown its full commitment to a family planning program that has been internationally acknowledged as one of the most successful efforts in the world today.
I quote another UNFPA official:
China's ability to reduce the natural growth rate from 2.4 per cent to 1.4 per cent in the past decade has been a `fantastic achievement'.

That was by Aprodicio Laquian, China country program director of the UNFPA. There is no mention of or deference to the well-known abuses of human rights involved in that program in both China and Tibet.

The sad part about it was that when Nafis Sadik came to Australia to sell UNFPA, she went before the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, gave her line there and was not questioned. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) says in statements to people who write to him that, among other things, UNFPA does not regard abortion as an appropriate means of family planning. Let me quote Nafis Sadik, who is now the international director of UNFPA and who wrote in a research article into the regulation of human fertility. She said:

I would say that a menses inducer which was self-administered perhaps could really change the course of family planning programs. Such a device would free women from having to ask anybody, husband or physician-a woman would then be free to take something, not after coitus or at any other time, but only when she thought she was pregnant.

That is UNFPA's and Nafis Sadik's attitude on that subject. So far as the International Planned Parenthood Federation is concerned, the United States Government again will not give one cent of US taxpayers' funds to that body. One of the reasons for that is that IPPF refused to sign the US-Mexico City policy and therefore removed itself from being able to receive US aid funds. The IPPF is in the forefront of moves to get a number of countries to have easier access to abortions. Here are our taxpayers' funds going to these organisations through the back door now; the environment assistance program being used to fund these organisations.

I believe that it is an outrageous situation where the total aid budget has been slashed by 7 per cent and the funds for overseas development assistance have been slashed by $96m this year-slashed in areas including agriculture, research, reafforestation and various other worthwhile programs-and yet money is able to be found for international lobby organisations such as UNFPA and IPPF. I think the Committee deserves an explanation on those particular matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has raised a whole heap of issues. The first one was to suggest that there was a $96m reduction in the Budget. Let me simply say straight out that that is not so. The aid budget increased by 1.6 per cent in real terms or $19.7m in monetary terms this year. It is not as much as I would have liked, but it did represent a significant achievement in circumstances of real constraint. The figure of a $96m reduction that Senator Harradine has come up with is based on some rather spurious figuring by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, ACFOA, which bases it on a calculation of $1,174m being the basic aid vote in 1989-90, which was inflated by the bringing forward $100m of payments to financial institutions to that year. Then that was inflated by 7 per cent, an arbitrary figure that the Council used for inflation to come to a notional total for this year of $1,363m. When compared to the $1,267m that was actually put on the table by the Government, that represents a shortfall of $96m. But all of that calculation is suspect, not least for the 7 per cent inflation figure. The actual figure that was used by the Government was not 7 per cent but 6.1 per cent, which makes a significant difference to the figuring. Again, the effects of the bring forwards have been capable of all sorts of manipulation for public presentational purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say in that respect is that while it is the case that bring forwards increased 1988-89 expenditure-for reasons that are well known to the aid agencies-by approximately $100m, in the year before and in the two years after that aid has stayed constant in real terms. That has been the pattern pretty well since the large shortfall occurred in 1986. We have striven very hard to maintain the aid budget in real terms.

Where difficulties have arisen for this year's aid budget is not in any shortfall of the kind that Senator Harradine or ACFOA has identified, but simply by virtue of yet another significant drain on the aid budget being required this year as a result of commitments falling due in a way that had not previously been anticipated to international financial institutions-some $100m of extra commitments this year. Since the aid budget was effectively finite and we were able to get only a small increase from the previous year, not enough to accommodate the whole of that $100m, as much as I tried, that meant that there was very considerable pressure placed elsewhere on the aid budget because of the need to divert expenditure into the Asian Development Bank and World Bank commitments that I have just described.

That has made it necessary for there to be reductions in some other areas-regrettable deductions, certainly. I accept the point that is made about agricultural research. The drop back from $6.6m to $5.6m was regrettable. We were able pretty well to preserve ACR's real income intact and a number of other major projects but there as elsewhere, with a lot of bilateral programs and a lot of multilateral programs, we simply had to shave, shave, shave.

Our Overseas Service Bureau was one area that was shaved a little as compared with the expectations of that organisation, but in practice my understanding is that arrangements have been made to ensure that the number of Australian volunteers abroad operates at roughly the levels that have been established in recent years; namely, some 250 volunteers at a time. I have recently made available some additional money from another source within the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau budget to overcome a particular perceived problem in that area. I think Mr Armstrong and his organisation accept that. Certainly they have not been on my back in recent months. I think Senator Harradine's criticism is a little outdated in that respect.

As for reduction here in these areas being accompanied by some massive increase in the population funding program, it is the case that there has been some increase overall but the orders of magnitude are very small-$4.5m up to $5.3m for a very wide ranging program that is by no means confined to the UNFPA itself. It extends to a number of other international organisations and organisations in particular countries like, for example, our population and family health project in Bangladesh.

I make absolutely no apology at all for the priority and the gradually increasing priority that we in the Government have been giving to family planning programs. I regard population issues as quite central in development policy. That is the view of most professionals in the field around the world and it is a view to which I will adhere. I do not accept the allegations that continue to be made by Senator Harradine about the UNFPA and coercive activities allegedly being supported by it in China. We have investigated that particular assertion which has been made periodically by the US agency to which he refers, but not to my knowledge by anyone else. It is not an allegation that we have found substantiated. I just want to make it absolutely clear that what Senator Harradine says about the UNFPA is, I believe, misconceived. It is a pity that he continues to ride that particular horse. It is not one that is justified and I am going to stick to my guns in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with everything said by Senator Cooney. I wish to address the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and my view is that the Privacy Amendment Bill is still in a totally unsatisfactory form. However, so far as the work of the Committee is concerned, it has done its job admirably. Honourable senators who are participating in this Committee of the Whole may not be aware that we have probably saved about a week's sitting. No doubt Senator Tate will take that back to Senator Robert Ray as a demonstration that the new committee system can work well when it is approached in a spirit of goodwill, is well chaired, is well staffed and there is good backup staff on all sides.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be the first to acknowledge that this piece of proposed legislation is now in far better shape than when it was referred to the Committee. That means that as it will pass tonight we are happier than if it had not gone through that process, although we still have some fundamental concerns with the Bill. Unfortunately, the committee procedure is not one whereby we can achieve fundamental change and, although we went into the Committee with high hopes, they were perhaps a little unrealistic.

We have agreed from the start that there is a need for regulation in this area-that of controlling credit reference reporting. It is interesting that the industry also agreed to that from the start of this debate. The dispute has been primarily- really wholly-about what is the best and correct way to regulate the industry.

This Bill, which is now back before the Committee of the Whole, severely restricts the current use of credit reference reporting and totally prohibits it from being used by real estate agents, insurance companies and many others; and we think that that is regrettable, to say the least. It gives no automatic notification to individuals that access has been had to their files in these areas and it does not adequately reflect the information privacy principles set out in the Privacy Act 1988.

The Opposition moved, in total, over 50 amendments to the Bill and to the Government amendments. The object of our amendments was to allow credit reference reporting for most commercial users, to make the Bill more practical and realistic, and to provide real protection for consumers. It is unfortunate that so few of our amendments have the necessary support in this chamber.

It will no doubt be acknowledged that the Government has also moved many amendments to the Bill, particularly as a result of consultations over the past few months. We are supporting some of those amendments as far as they go towards improving the Bill, particularly those which will allow mortgage and trade insurers access to credit reporting services. The Government amendments to which the Opposition is either opposed or has moved amendments are Government amendments Nos 2, 7, 8, 9, 14, 15, 16, 19, 30, 36, 40, 41, 44, 45, 45A, 46 and 47.

The amendments moved by the Opposition fall under a number of different heads. I will briefly remind the Senate of them. The first is the artificial distinction between consumer and commercial credit. The Bill is based upon this artificial distinction. We have argued that the two should not be separated when, in practice, they often cannot be separated. The Government's argument in favour of its position has been that the industry would be moving towards positive reporting, which has been denied by the industry.

The proposal to separate consumer and commercial credit reporting also very significantly weakens the protective mechanisms of the Bill for individuals who are engaged in small business ventures. If a person applies for a personal loan and credit is refused because of information in a credit report, the credit provider must inform the person that the report was responsible for the refusal. The person then has a right of access to the report and has the right to challenge any information contained in it. If the report contains false or misleading information, the individual may also have a right to claim compensation.

If the same person, however, applies for a commercial loan and the application is refused because of a credit report, he does not need to be told the reason for the refusal and he has no right of access to the report and no right to query its accuracy. We believe that that distinction defies logic. The important point is that the distinction between commercial and consumer finance is often blurred, with working capital, including business borrowings, being applied to household as well as business users and personal finances being added to working capital.

The second area of great concern that we took to the Committee and that I want to mention again at this stage of debate in dealing with the Committee's report relates to publicly available information. Publicly available information is exempt from the provisions of the Bill. In the credit reporting context, such information includes details of writs, summonses and judgments recorded against an individual. The Opposition is of the view that this type of information is too important to be exempt from the privacy protection afforded by the Bill. It should not be so exempt, otherwise there is nothing to stop any person setting up a database comprised exclusively of such information and operating completely outside the scope of the Bill.

The Bill assumes that publicly available information is correct. The fact is that, once it is entered on a file, it may not be correct. Writs and summonses may be the subject of dispute and may be successfully defended; judgments may be set aside. If a file is not updated to reflect such changes it will result in a person being refused credit on the basis of wrong information. A person refused credit under such circumstances would not be advised of the reason for the refusal and would have no right of access to the information. There would be no procedure for the correction of wrong information.

The third remaining shortcoming that I want to refer to is in relation to monitoring. The Opposition amendments relate to a situation where it has become obvious that an individual is in default with several credit providers. The amendments allow a credit provider to `monitor' a customer so that he can be aware that a person is in financial difficulty with other creditors. They act to protect both the consumer, by possibly preventing insolvency, and the credit provider, by possibly preventing a bad debt.

I stress that our amendments would not have allowed the system of general surveillance of that information. Information on a file could be used only in considering the appropriateness of financial counselling, a rearrangement of the individual's credit commitments, or a reassessment of his credit limit.

In view of the lack of support for the Opposition amendments, we are reluctantly accepting the Australian Democrats' amendment, which allows a credit reporting agency to disclose information contained in a file where the agency has received information at least 30 days before the disclosure that a person is at least 60 days overdue in making a payment. In our view, we accept that as a second best situation.

The fourth area of shortcoming is that relating to general insurance. Under this Bill general insurers are excluded from access to credit information. This, in the Opposition's view, ignores the very serious problem of insurance fraud. The Opposition's resistance to this move by the Government has received widespread support. For example, I remind you, Mr Chairman, that at the Australian Insurance Law Association conference in Melbourne last year Douglas Meagher, QC, said that the Bill would make it almost impossible, firstly, to identify and then to investigate fraudulent claims. Organised fraud would be virtually undetectable.

There are many examples which clearly highlight the close relationship between insurance fraud and prior financial problems. At a time when insurance fraud is running at $1.5 billion a year, in our view the Government should not be introducing legislation which will make fraud even easier.

The fifth area of shortcoming which I want to raise in this Committee relates to the real estate industry. Under this Bill, real estate agents are excluded from access to credit information files. At present, there are 650 real estate firms across Australia which are members of the Credit Reference Association. These firms represent approximately 90 per cent of all agencies involved in property management. They use credit bureau files for the purpose of assessing tenancy applications. They do so because of a duty to their clients to check the bona fides of prospective tenants. The correlation between credit problems and unsatisfactory tenancies has been recognised for many years. In fact, in 1986 the Real Estate Institute of New South Wales was able to demonstrate this to the New South Wales Privacy Committee to the extent that the Committee reversed its original recommendation that real estate agents be excluded from access to credit files.

Although landlords have a number of protections available to them, such as rental bonds, it is not unusual for an unsatisfactory tenant to cease payment of rents some weeks before moving out, thus negating any protection the landlord may have had. If real estate agents cannot use credit reporting services, it will be a simple commercial necessity to set up tenant databases in each State. Because these databases will be outside the legislation, there will be no regulation and no automatic protection of the rights of individuals to access their files and no procedure to correct any wrong information. It is not a position the industry wants but it will be imposed upon it by the effect of this legislation.

The sixth area that I want to refer to is amendments relating to the recording of information on, access to or use of information on credit reference files. These amendments relate to guarantors, collection agents, company directors, other credit providers, trustees in bankruptcy and liquidators. We are pleased that the Government is accepting our amendment 14A, which adds a provision for the recording of an inquiry by a credit provider about someone who has offered to act as a guarantor. It is disappointing, however, that the remaining amendments in this category have not received the same support. In particular, the exclusion of mercantile agents will have serious effects for small businesses which presently use those agents to collect debts. Those businesses will be forced to join the Credit Reference Association in order to use its information, thus making credit recovery more expensive.

The seventh area that I want to refer to is dishonoured cheques. The Opposition is of the view that the presentation of cheques which are then dishonoured should be among the permitted contents of credit information files. Such behaviour is frequently an indication of credit difficulties, even though a dishonoured cheque given in payment for goods and services does not necessarily involve the extension of credit by a credit provider-for example, it may be for goods delivered cash on delivery by a retail store. Because the Opposition's amendments have not received the necessary support, the Opposition is supporting the Democrats' amendments on this matter, again as a compromise measure. These amendments provide for the recording of information about dishonoured cheques in certain limited circumstances.

The eighth category that I want to refer to relates to transitional provisions or those affecting use of information collected prior to the commencement of the Bill. Because of time constraints, somebody else may have to say something before I have the opportunity to finish what I want to say.

This is a far more realistic picture of the groups which were likely to require the services of credit reporting agencies. We were unsuccessful in this instance.

The Opposition moved three amendments relating to the role of the Privacy Commissioner, which I am pleased to note have received support from both the Government and the Democrats. Opposition amendment No.10 adds a further consideration for the Privacy Commissioner to take into account when preparing the code of conduct the likely costs to credit reporting agencies and their users. After all, there is no use in having standards in the code which are so costly, either to the agencies or their users, that their implementation is impractical.

Opposition amendment No. 26 opposes Government amendment No.34 - proposed new subsections 18K(5) and (6). I understand that amendment No. 34 is being withdrawn. That is a wise decision as it is extremely bureaucratic in that it provides that the Commissioner may determine the manner in which information may be disclosed, including the manner in which an individual's consent may be obtained. Opposition amendment No. 27 achieves the same result with respect to the Bill itself as the previous amendment achieves with respect to the Government's amendments.

I now turn to word limits. Under Opposition amendment No.18, where an individual requests a statement concerning a disputed matter to be added to his file the maximum length of the statement is 100 words. Since the credit reporting agency is obliged to add such statements to the file, it is reasonable to limit the length of the statement to prevent files becoming unmanageably large. Because this amendment will not receive the necessary support, the Opposition will be supporting the Democrats' compromise amendment on this subject, which gives the Privacy Commissioner the power to determine what is reasonable in any circumstances of dispute.

In relation to consent, Opposition amendment No. 22 removes the requirement for a trade insurer to have the written permission of an individual to access that person's credit file. The amendment is necessary because trade insurers do not have direct contact with the individual whose debt a credit provider is seeking to insure. Therefore, obtaining the individual's written permission would be a difficult and impractical exercise. The Opposition proposes instead that there be a requirement that the individual must have been informed in writing by the credit provider before any access by the trade insurer.

The tenth area of concern which we raised is that of appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). The Opposition had moved an amendment to provide for an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from a decision of the Privacy Commissioner. The object of the amendment was to provide some appeal mechanism short of the very expensive and formal Federal Court. However, we have agreed not to pursue this amendment on the understanding that the question of the jurisdiction of the AAT in matters arising under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission legislation generally is to be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for examination under its cost of justice reference.

Finally, there were a series of amendments which have become known as the Corrs-the legal firm-amendments. That firm of solicitors recently raised the matter of a number of types of transactions which would be adversely affected by the introduction of the Bill. The types of transactions include the sale of loan debts, the sale of a credit provider which owns loan debts and the taking of security over loan debts.

As the Bill was originally drafted, the purchaser or chargee would have been unable to obtain vital information relating to the loans. The Government conceded that these effects were largely unintended consequences and has proposed amendments which meet some of the concerns raised, specifically so that disclosure is allowed to related corporations and to corporations which are proposing to accept an assignment of a debt owed to a credit provider, to accept a debt as a security for a loan or to purchase an interest in a credit provider.

Whilst we accept that, we do not believe that the Government's suggested amendments cover all the necessary points. In a few minutes we will be moving a further series of amendments under this head, some of which, we understand, will be accepted by the Government and some of which will not be accepted. The purpose of our amendments is to allow disclosure to the professional advisers of a corporation and to the managers of loan portfolios.

In summary, whilst we think that the Bill is now a technically better Bill than when it last left the Senate and entered the committee process, nevertheless, there are still a number of fundamental shortcomings that I have referred to tonight which will not make it possible for us to support the Bill at the third reading stage.

We regret that the Government has remained ideologically blinkered in this exercise, that it has not been able to take up these areas of reform which, I would have thought on any effective assessment, have a great deal of merit. The Government has also not been prepared to take up the Bill which we introduced in the other chamber as an alternative and better approach to regulating the credit reference industry. Nevertheless, before I sit down I reiterate my thanks to all of those who have endeavoured during this process to improve the legislation and to make our early experiment with the new standing committee procedure in the consideration of Bills referred by the chamber, at least in this instance, a success.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a few brief points in relation to the Privacy Amendment Bill. Of course, I fully endorse Senator Hill's comments. The concerns that some of us have with this Bill were well expressed in the evidence that came before the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Senator Hill referred to the alternative Bill that has been introduced in the other place which addresses in a very real way many of the concerns that have been raised here. Not only business groups are concerned about this Bill; a major and detailed report was prepared on this Bill by the former Ombudsman, Professor Jack Richardson. The concerns he raised fully endorsed those matters that Senator Hill mentioned in his remarks.

I wish to raise two specific matters. One goes to a fundamental problem that we have in this chamber and in this Parliament that governments bring in Bills without any clear idea of their overall cost to the community at large. Some fairly horrendous costs were mentioned in the evidence brought before the Committee. It was put to the Committee that the likely cost of this Bill would range between $1.3 billion and $2.4 billion a year in fraud, bad debts and operational costs. It is interesting that, when this matter was raised with the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), it was fairly clear that the Government had no figures on the likely effects of this Bill on the industry. The costs stretching well over $1 billion were not in any way addressed by the Government in the evidence. When Senator Tate responds to the matters raised here today, I hope he will give some idea of the likely extra costs that this Bill will impose on the credit industry. By imposing extra costs on the credit industry, the Government is effectively imposing extra costs on all consumers. That is one matter that I wished to raise.

I also fully endorse other matters which Senator Hill mentioned about the rights of appeal. It became very apparent during the evidence which was brought before us that this Bill in many ways was not adequate; in one particular way, that it imposed very heavy burdens on those who wished to appeal against the determinations of the Privacy Commissioner.

The final matter I wish to raise has been very effectively expressed by Professor Jack Richardson in his report on the role given to the Privacy Commissioner by this Bill. On page 2 of the report Professor Richardson argues:

A disturbing feature of the legislation is the extensive powers and functions given to the Privacy Commissioner . . . The Commissioner's main tasks under the Act concern observance by Commonwealth agencies of information privacy principles. The Commissioner has yet to make good his role under the principal Act. The powers and functions which he is given under the Bill, will be exercised mainly in relation to private industry which operates quite differently from most government agencies.
He urges:
The Bill as it now reads is unbalanced and should not proceed in its present form.
Professor Richardson goes on to say:

The position is that the Commissioner performs a legislative function in issuing the Code of Conduct. He may then carry out the executive function of investigating possible breaches of his own Code and further proceed to the judicial type function of making a binding determination which he may seek to enforce through a court. In my view the combination of the three types of function in a single Commonwealth functionary is objectionable.

I would like to conclude by stating my concerns, which were stated in the evidence which has come before us, about the role that this Government has defined for the Privacy Commissioner. It is a matter which I will be seeking to pursue in other channels, but not tonight.

``(7) References in subsection (6) to information that is not information of a kind referred to in subsection 18e (1) do not include references to information the disclosure of which is taken, because of the application of subsection 18k (1b), not to be in contravention of subsection 18k (1a).

``(8) In spite of anything in this section to the contrary, this section does not impose any obligations on a person in relation to a report or information obtained under paragraph 18n (1) (e), (ea) or (eb), or in relation to any personal information derived from such a report or information, unless:

``(9) A person who knowingly or recklessly contravenes subsection (1), (2), (3), (4) or (5) is guilty of an offence punishable, on conviction, by a fine not exceeding $30,000.''.
(11) Government amendment 46, omit ``or 18nb''.

The need for these amendments, which I mentioned a while ago, was also foreshadowed at the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. As is noted in paragraph 8 of the Committee's report, the amendments relate to certain types of technical but nevertheless reasonably common commercial transactions which would have been adversely affected by the Privacy Amendment Bill as originally drafted, including the sale of loan debts, whether specifically or in the course of the sale of a business; the sale of a credit provider which owns loan debts; and the taking of security over loan debts whether by taking a charge over debts specifically or over the assets of a company generally where the assets include loan debts.

The Opposition is of the view that four separate extensions are required in relation to the circumstances in which disclosure may occur in order to avert these adverse consequences while still recognising the need to regulate access to personal information in order to protect the privacy of the individual.

First, an amendment is necessary to take account of the normal prudent commercial practice in which either before or after buying a loan debt the purchaser makes a due diligence inquiry about the debtor in order to obtain the information necessary to evaluate the loan debt. This information would include the name and address of the debtor, the amount of indebtedness, the terms of the loan and whether the debtor is credit worthy. Under the Bill as originally drafted, the purchaser or chargee would have been unable to obtain this vital information. Similarly, where a credit provider which owns loan debts is being sold, the purchaser of the credit provider's shares would have been prevented from carrying out a due diligence inquiry as to the assets of the credit provider. Secondly, an amendment is required to allow the provision of information to related corporations.

The Government conceded that there was a need to address these two issues and has proposed amendments which the Opposition is accepting, allowing the disclosure of information to related corporations and the disclosure of information to a corporation that is considering whether to accept an assignment to the debt, to accept a debtor's security for a loan or whether to purchase an interest in the credit provider. The Opposition is moving amendments which allow a purchaser, in these types of transactions, access to credit information after the purchase, recognising that it may be impractical to do a due diligence inquiry on every debt in a portfolio beforehand and it may well be necessary at some stage afterwards.

The third area where problems would have arisen is in the context of loan portfolio management, where a credit provider or person who acquires a loan debt wishes to appoint an unrelated manager to manage it. The Opposition is proposing the necessary amendment to provide for the manager, in these circumstances, to have the access to credit information which he or she would obviously need. For example, such circumstances may arise where the credit provider simply decides that this is the most efficient means of management or where a chargee in respect of a loan portfolio wants, in the event of a default, to take possession of the charge loan debts and to appoint a manager to act on his or her behalf. The situation also arises in respect of an increasingly common type of transaction called debt securitisation, in which a credit provider sells debts to a buyer, who then appoints the seller as manager of the loan portfolio. If the seller does not perform his or her obligations, the buyer has a right to appoint another unrelated manager. It may also be necessary to appoint a manager of a loan portfolio where a credit provider or person who acquires a portfolio becomes insolvent.

Fourthly, the Opposition is proposing amendments to provide for the disclosure of information to a credit provider's professional legal and professional financial advisers. Access by such people may be necessary, for example, to vary the terms of a loan, to advise on its enforceability or to advise on tax consequences of a loan. The Opposition is of the view that a credit provider's professional legal and professional financial advisers should have access to credit information as is generally necessary for them to perform their advisory functions.

The Opposition is also moving an amendment which will specifically allow access to credit information for the professional legal and professional financial advisers of a corporation that is a prospective purchaser in three types of transactions: the sale of loan debts, whether specifically or in the course of the sale of a business; the sale of a credit provider which owns loan debts; and the taking of security over loan debts whether by taking a charge over debts specifically or over the assets of a company generally where the assets include loan debts. We are further proposing an amendment which will allow disclosure of credit information to the professional legal and professional financial advisers of a corporation which is a related credit provider.

The Opposition had considered a further amendment to ensure that auditors of a company would have access to credit information about its debtors. However, we have accepted the Government's assurance that the general powers to inspect accounts and records given to auditors in companies legislation is sufficient to allow them unrestricted access to credit information. Therefore, we will not be pursuing the matter at this stage.

I understand that the Government has indicated that it will be agreeing to some Opposition amendments and opposing others. I suggest that the Committee consider amendments Nos 1, 3, 4 and 6 together and then the remaining amendments Nos 2, 5 and 7 to 13 together.

Amendments 1, 3, 4 and 6 would bring into effect the Opposition's policy that professional legal and professional financial advisers should have access to credit information as is generally necessary for them to perform their advisory functions. They would also allow disclosure of credit information to the professional legal and professional financial advisers of a corporation which is related to the credit provider.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It might suit the convenience of the Committee if I gave the Government response in relation not only to amendments Nos 1, 3, 4 and 6 moved by the Opposition but also foreshadowed amendments Nos 2, 5 and 7 to 13 moved by Senator Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is prepared to accept the modifications proposed by the Opposition parties to Government amendments 40, 45A and 46 as adopted by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The combined effect of these Government amendments is, broadly, to make provisions which will permit the continuation of legitimate commerical practices relating to the selling and purchasing of debts, the provision of security over debts and the management by credit providers of their loans.

The amendments proposed by the Opposition will extend the permitted scope of access to credit information to the professional legal and financial advisers of corporate credit providers. Although this was not provided for in the Government's original proposals, which were the subject of the recommendations by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the Government accepts that there is a need to allow bona fide advisers to have access to information without which they could not properly discharge their advising function.

The Government also accepts that the widened scope of access to facilitate accepted commercial practices related to buying and selling debts and taking securities over debts should include provision for access by a corporate credit provider where this would be necessary in order to permit the exercise of rights arising from the initial agreement. Thus, where the right of access is not taken up at the same time as the agreement in question, the access will be permitted to occur at a later stage.

The Government notes that this wider access is limited only to the categories of persons who would normally be expected to have a need for such information. Moreover, appropriate limitations on the use and disclosure of the information are specifically provided to ensure the integrity of the privacy protection aspects of the Bill.

The Government is unable to accept, however, the proposal that access be granted to an adviser merely `for use in performing his or her function' as an adviser. Such a purpose is too widely defined to be acceptable from a privacy protection perspective. While access in such cases may be convenient, such widely drawn purposes do not identify a particular need on the part of the credit provider's adviser in the context of advising on matters relevant to the provision of credit.

As a result, the Government accepts Opposition amendments 2, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12 and 13 and opposes Opposition amendments 1, 3, 4 and 6. It also notes that amendments 9, 10, and 12 will require some minor deletions to reflect the decision of the Committee not to accept Opposition amendment 3.
Amendments 1, 3, 4 and 6 negatived.
Amendments 2, 5 and 7 to 11 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.

I rise to speak on this third reading of the Privacy Amendment Bill 1989 [1990]. In so doing, I am of course aware that this is a somewhat unusual procedure. Nevertheless, as I shall shortly explain, I will justify this indulgence on two separate but important grounds. First and foremost, this is, of course, a red letter day for the Australian consumer. For the first time consumers will be given a statutory right to have access to that most important piece of personal information-their personal credit file. Where that file contains information which is out of date or incorrect the consumer will have the right to have the file rectified. The Bill also creates the further right to complain to the Privacy Commissioner and to seek an order for compensation for damages suffered through any infringement of privacy.

I think all honourable senators will agree that these are fundamental rights in our modern society where a person's credit rating has assumed an unparalleled level of importance. Equally importantly, the Bill also imposes limitations on the uses of personal credit information. In particular the Bill firmly and unequivocally puts an end to any possibility of positive reporting in Australia. I am pleased to say that we in Australia will now never experience the extremely intrusive practices which have grown up in the United States and which have been so graphically documented in the recent reports of the New South Wales Privacy Committee. On the contrary, consumers may now, thanks to this Bill, rest safe in the knowledge that the information they provide about their personal financial affairs will only ever be used for purposes which have a direct and relevant bearing upon credit.

In a more general sense, the Bill represents a very significant further step forward in the Government's program to empower the consumer in an increasingly complex financial environment. As I indicated when addressing the annual general meeting of the Australian Consumers Association in Sydney last Tuesday, there is an undeniable and increasing need for consumer protection and awareness of consumer rights in the modern, deregulated Australian economy. I believe Australia should take a lead from the recent developments in the European Community, where a series of deregulative measures affecting financial matters have precipitated concurrent steps to ensure community-wide protection for consumers against deceptive, improper and unfair trading practices. I say here, as I said then, that precisely the same concurrent activity must be an absolute priority in Australia's own deregulated marketplace. I can assure the Senate that, as Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, I am certainly doing my bit to ensure that result.

In that context this Bill sits firmly alongside other important consumer and financial developments which I have been able to secure. I refer to such matters as the agreement on uniform national credit legislation achieved at the meeting of consumer affairs Ministers in Perth in July.

All of these initiatives draw upon a common theme-the consumer is entitled to be informed and, where wronged, the consumer should have a means of effective redress. Undoubtedly, this Bill will play its own part in ensuring that Australian consumers have both the information and the means to more confidently assert the role that has been laid out for them in that deregulated marketplace.

My second reason for speaking at this time is of more peculiar interest to those in this chamber. Many honourable senators no doubt would have passed an exhibition presently set up in the public area of the first floor of this building marking the twentieth anniversary of the establishment of the Senate committee structure as we know it. I mention this because I believe the passage of this Bill has made a little history of its own. Indeed, it may be that in 10 years time the events surrounding this Bill will occupy a little space in the display which is established at that time. If ever there was a Bill which was going to really test the new procedures, it was this one. Not only were the issues technical and complex, but also over the 18 months or so which have elapsed since its introduction into the Senate some 120 further amendments from the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats were brought forward. In the event, the Committee was able to meet in a highly constructive fashion. Evidence was received from five witnesses, including the Privacy Commissioner himself. In the course of the examination of those witnesses virtually all significant issues were discussed in an informed and productive way.

When it came to consideration of the amendments, the Committee was able to quickly resolve upon a series of agreed amendments which reflected the considered and lengthy discussions which had taken place between myself, Senator Powell, Senator Hill and our respective staffs. In short, the exercise has been a great success. Considerable time of the Senate has been saved without, I believe, any reduction in the quality of the consideration of the issues which took place. It remains for me, therefore, to formally acknowledge the contribution to the final Bill which was made by a variety of industry groups, including a contribution in the later stages by Mr Bruce Bargon of the Credit Reporting Association of Australia. I hasten to add that, while the Bill does not enjoy the unqualified support of these groups, they engaged in very productive consultations which resulted in a number of helpful suggestions which have gone a long way to ensuring that the Bill in its final form is as good as it can be.

Finally, I wish to publicly and formally acknowledge the very considerable work undertaken by my predecessor, Senator Bolkus. Senator Nick Bolkus was undoubtedly the first politician of national status to see the need for such a statutory based set of protections for the privacy of borrowers in the modern economy. He went through an exhausting set of meetings with industry and other interested groups towards the end of last year which in turn resulted in a significant number of improvements to the Bill. Whilst I have been able to build on his work, it was his initiative and his perseverance in the face of considerable hostility that have secured these very considerable protections for borrowers within the Australian community.

I wish to extend an invitation to those same organisations, together with all other government, commercial, consumer and other relevant bodies and organisations, to consult with the Privacy Commissioner over the next few months as he prepares the code of conduct required under the legislation. I am confident that all concerned will wish to ensure that the final package-that is, both the Act and the code of conduct-is the very best that can be achieved in the interests of all. I wish the Bill a speedy third reading.

I referred briefly to some of the areas where cuts have taken place. The cut in international agricultural research, though minor in dollar terms, was substantial in percentage terms.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the point made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) prior to dinner. Senator Evans addressed the point that I made as to why these programs were cut when we were able to increase by 44 per cent the amount going to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) and the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF). The Minister has just said that he personally had indicated that that was where he wanted that money to go. He is nothing if not honest. He has stated perfectly clearly on a number of occasions that he has a high priority in this area. At page 58 of the Estimates Committee B Hansard, he is reported as saying:
I happen to believe that family planning is the highest single aid priority in the world at the moment.

I feel that is an extraordinary statement by anyone in this field of development assistance. It makes certain basic assumptions which are not held by anyone that I know; certainly not by anyone who is across the development assistance field. A World Bank official had a view on this subject which was not as extreme as Senator Evans's view. I believe her view influenced World Bank policy to a certain extent for some time. I referred to that author-Nancy Birdsall-at the Estimates Committee. The Estimates Committee Hansard shows that Senator Evans had not even heard of Nancy Birdsall. Anybody who is at all across the area of development assistance would have heard of Nancy Birdsall and would also have heard of a later paper which she prepared in which she said:

There is no consensus on the effects of rapid population growth on economic growth in developing countries. The assumption that rapid population growth was detrimental prevailed in the 1950s and 1960s-when the literature emphasized lack of capital (and savings) coupled with surplus labor in agriculture as the major constraints to economic growth.

This is not the time to carry on this argument except to say that, if Senator Evans has got it wrong, the whole of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau has got it wrong-if it is following what Senator Evans is saying. If it follows and carries out his top priority, which is that he believes family planning is the highest single priority in the world at the moment, we are dooming large numbers of people in developing countries to desperate poverty because we are not attacking the basic cause of poverty. I feel that the Minister needs to open his mind a little. He owes it to the taxpayers of Australia and to the poverty stricken people in developing countries to open his mind about the other possibilities and causes of poverty and underdevelopment.

A growing body of literature indicates that other factors are more significant, to such an extent that the assertion that population growth is a crucial negative factor in economic development is no longer sustainable. It is an assertion that must be questioned if we are to go to the true causes of poverty. In effect, to blame people growth as the problem and population control as the solution is to do a grave disservice to developing countries.

There are a large number of problems involved and causes of poverty. I will name a few: the indebtedness of debt ridden countries to the Western financial institutions; the need to overcome unemployment; the need to assist with making fisheries and farming more attractive; the need to exchange technologies with developing countries to promote the environmentally sound and efficient use of resources; the need to reform inefficient or corrupt economic practices; the need to promote human initiatives.

I note UNFPA's own document, which was sent around to schools by AIDAB. That was a one-sided effort if ever I saw one and I will come to that in a minute. It talked about the reduction of food production in Africa. Questions must be asked as to why that has occurred. The solution offered by UNFPA-and we are throwing money at it-is population control. Of course, UNFPA is on the band wagon, but has the Minister read the statements made by the Food and Agriculture Organisation, which says that one country in Africa-Zaire-could feed the whole of Africa seven times over with just moderate agricultural input? Yet, as I understand it, there are food shortages in Zaire. There is a recent book about this subject from a woman's point of view which I feel the Minister should read. It was published only last year. It states:

The power structures analysis poses one additional question to those advocating family planning as a means of enhancing human well-being and alleviating stress on the environment: Can reducing births reduce poverty, hunger and environmental degradation? Since rapid population growth is not the cause of these closely intertwined problems, we doubt that simply slowing growth can alleviate them.

I am addressing the whole area and thrust, it now appears, of the Minister with his fixation on this area. I believe it is essential that at some stage he at least looks at the evidence and the literature on this question. To go to the UNFPA, the Minister has again made an assertion that AIDAB has looked at it. AIDAB had better look at it more thoroughly than it looked at the China problem. It did not even have the material-the Department of Foreign Affairs might have had it-on China. Does it have the material on UNFPA? There is more available than what I have just quoted. The International Planned Parenthood Federation has been supplying vacuum aspiration kits for some developing countries-in other words, abortion kits. That organisation has been the most outspoken advocate of legal abortion services in developing countries. Perhaps we ought to have it all out on the table to see just who we are supporting, because it is being done through the back door. Thirty-five per cent of the program we are discussing-that is, the environmental assistance program-is going to these population control organisations.

Finally, I would like to refer to the educational material funded by this Budget. I believe a similar approach has been taken. It is an unbalanced approach, an approach where AIDAB has only had one eye on the subject and, extraordinary to say, it has not bothered to provide school students, among whom--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid I lack shame on the subject of my commitment to family planning and population control as a crucially important element in the aid program and in development assistance strategies internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: I confess that hitherto the existence of Nancy Birdsall and her contribution to the literature on this subject has eluded me. I am entirely familiar, however, from innumerable discussions of development problems in many Third World countries, with how many other people in positions of leadership in those countries are struggling with the problems of poverty, health and every other set of personal tragedies that go with that. I am not surprised at how many others are less inclined to elevate Ms Birdsall to a position of superiority over the evidence of their own eyes and over their own commitment to population programs and strategies.

I call in aid quite specifically, as one particular authority whom I think I am entitled to draw some confidence from in this respect, in his identification of population problems as an appropriate development assistance priority, Mr Joe Wheeler, the chairman of DAC, the Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. He, more than anyone else, is charged with the responsibility of coordinating, shaping and stimulating the developed world's response to the horrendous problems of poverty that afflict so many of our friends in other countries. He made a very explicit point to me-unprovoked, unstimulated and unprompted-when he said that one of the things which puzzled DAC about the Australian aid commitment was the dearth of resources, the poverty of the resources, that Australia devotes to the greatest single, most significant and important aid strategy of them all, family planning and population issues. He said to me just a few months ago in Australia that we ought to be spending at least around $20m on those programs rather than what was then the $4.5m, which I managed to get up to $5.3m, as I have said, in the last Budget.

There is a perception all round the place as to the centrality of this issue. Of course, it is the case that indebtedness and the accumulated impact of that is a very serious problem which contributes enormously to the poverty issues we see. Food production problems may be capable of rectification through green revolutions and appropriate mobilisation of resources; nonetheless, the problem of drought and seasonal crisis is a reinforcing cause of disaster in so many countries which are struggling with over-population trying to share a very limited cake. When those sorts of production problems arise, the problem becomes exponentially worse.

There are problems of poor administration in a lot of the countries in question that would do much to alleviate the misallocation of resources which presently exists. There are problems of lack of access to markets for commodities which do not enable the flow of income that would be able to sustain, yes, a higher population. That is one of the things we are trying to address in the context of the Uruguay Round-the desperate imbalance and the unfairness which exist in the world trading environment so far as the position of developing countries is concerned. Problems of war and civil strife all accentuate the difficulties of scratching out a tenuous existence in so many countries. But it beggars the imagination that the world's population, which has exploded over the past two decades to 5.5 billion, the present number-increasing all the time-is not in itself a hugely contributing factor to the poverty experience of people in so many countries.

It is impossible to believe the reduction in those rates of growth of population. Stabilisation of their population balance would not contribute markedly and indeed massively to population alleviation in those countries. As the lawyers say, res ipsa loquitur-the matter speaks for itself. It really is shriekingly obvious, and there is ample justification one can find for this in the accumulated authority of people addressing these issues all over the world.

I am not on some lonesome crusade in this respect, I inform Senator Harradine. I have no difficulty at all in discussing these issues with AIDAB which has always had population programs very high on its list, and indeed has been increasingly taking the view that it does deserve to be left to the highest ranking authority; a view it is reaching quite independently of my own known preferences on the subject.

But even with all of that, I repeat that in an aid budget of $1.2 billion we are devoting now just over $5m to population programs. On almost any view of the nature and magnitude of the problem, it simply represents a proportionally very small contribution within our total aid budget. I think we are destined, as we both know, to go on disagreeing about this time immemorial into perpetuity. Senator Harradine can state his point of view and I will state mine. I am happy to look at any authorities that he wants to cite and push in my direction so that I can be better informed about the range of considered and informed views on this subject.

I am certainly happy to scrutinise very closely the way in which particular programs do operate. For all the reasons I indicated earlier today, I do not believe they should be coercive. I think it should be a matter of education, of propaganda, of incentive to insignificant extent, and of government strategy generally, but I do not think anyone should be in the business of coercion here. That apart, there is not much more we can usefully debate on an occasion like this. We just are destined to have a different view of the world.

1) What steps have been taken to rectify the supply of aviation fuel into RAAF Base-Tindal?
2) What steps are currently being taken to increase storage facilities beyond that of fuel storage for peace time operations?
3) Has the Department of Defence placed any value on the Alice-Darwin railway as a further option for haulage for fuel?

The response I received indicated very clearly that there is a proposal to nearly double the storage capacity at Tindal. The answer states that it `is intended for authorisation this financial year'. The answer continues:

Additionally, reserve quantities held in the contractor's storage at Port Darwin are also slated for review. Other discussed storage in the Darwin area is also under investigation to determine its potential usefulness for all three services.

I find the answer inadequate in that very obviously the Department of Defence is acknowledging that there is a very major problem with regard to the provision of aviation fuel at RAAF Base Tindal to guarantee and ensure that the proper operation of that base, and in effect the fighter aircraft, can properly be carried out. I think the acknowledgment that there is a proposal to double the storage capacity highlights that matter.

We are told that the reserve quantities that are to be held in Darwin are `slated for review' or `under investigation'. These are not satisfactory answers in view of the seriousness of the problem. I would like the Minister to assure me that this matter is receiving a very serious commitment from government; that there will not be any question of the operation of important aircraft or the base at Tindal being compromised in any way.
The other issue that I would like the Minister to consider concerns the long term commitment to the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. The Department in its answer to this part of my question stated:

The Department recognises the undoubted benefits to Defence interests that would accrue from the construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway but it is not in a position to contribute funding to such an endeavour.
I think the acknowledgment by Defence of the undoubted benefits is very important to the long term planning of that transport route. I also note the following statement in the answer:
The Department is also investigating alternatives to railway transport of fuels.

That returns to the first question with regard to the storage capability. I would like an assurance from the Minister that, firstly, the Department of Defence recognises that the undoubted benefits of the railway have met with some sympathy from the Government and are part of the long term commitments. Secondly, I would like to know more details about the alternatives to railway transport that are being pursued and the timing of the consideration of any of these subsequent reports and Budget considerations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The alternatives to rail are obviously road and sea. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: -I do not wish to keep the Committee very long. I have only a few matters which I would like to raise this evening. I would like to comment on a couple of items in the report. The report referred to one item when it states:

SPEECH.PARA: One specific area raised during the hearings was the need to develop measures to evaluate effectiveness of the various advertising campaigns undertaken by the department.

In my questioning during the Estimates Committee hearings about an advertising campaign entitled `Bottom Line', it was quite clear that there was a need not just in that campaign but apparently in all the Department of Defence advertising to have a proper evaluation process. It is a serious matter because there is considerable expenditure by the Department of Defence on advertising. I cannot imagine any private sector firm undertaking the Department's expenditure on advertising without knowing exactly how it was being targeted, how effective it was, whether the money was well spent with this agency or that agency and whether it was achieving the results that were sought. I find it strange, after all the years that the Department of Defence has been a major advertiser it does not have these programs in place. I am glad that the report referred to that.

It is not only in advertising that the Department appears to be deficient in evaluation and cost benefit analysis. For example, I draw attention to the education allowance. For a number of years I have been plugging away at the need to do better by our Defence Force personnel and their children. When the nation as a whole is looking to have a better educated population and it is becoming more and more important for young adults to have educational qualifications which will fit them for the challenges of the next century, it is very serious to disadvantage the children of these service personnel who have to move from State to State on a regular and overfrequent basis.

Recognising that the parent's employment requires this, it is clearly essential that the employer-in this case, the Commonwealth-make proper provision for mitigating these disadvantages that these children suffer. As a result, education allowance was introduced. Nevertheless, it has been provided in a most miserly manner. There is a great deficiency in its effectiveness, where it has been provided, in keeping defence personnel in the forces. We have not been told whether the use of this allowance has helped to keep people in the Force. I understand for instance in the British Defence forces, the educational allowance which provides assistance with boarding is widely regarded as a major incentive for keeping families in the Force. Yet, in Australia, the surveys that are done and the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force-Report and Recommendations-the Cross report -show that the education of secondary schoolchildren and the problems associated with it, is one of the major reasons that parents eventually decide to leave the Defence Force after massive amounts of money have been invested in their training.

One would want to know why no assessment appears to have been done about how effective that allowance is as a retention measure and how widely and effectively it is explained to members of the Defence Force. Clearly it is not being taken up in the numbers one would expect in the Force and I want to know why this is so. Year after year I have asked questions in the Estimates committee about this and we find that no improvement seems to be taking place. There does not seem to be a sense of urgency that this is an important issue going towards the retention of our high cost defence personnel. One has to ask why.

Another matter that does not seem to be evaluated is the question of school cadets. In questioning during the Estimates committee hearings this sitting, I received a number of answers relating to school cadets. One answer was that cadet units are not individually costed and the cost benefit analysis of a cadet unit can be applied only to regional cadet units which receive full support. Of course, they are few and far between. The representatives of the Royal Australian Air Force said that cost benefit analyses have not been conducted by the Air Force Office.

This is extraordinary because it is widely believed in the forces that school cadets in the past have been very important in providing a focus for recruitment of young people into the forces either at the other ranks level or, alternatively, as military officer cadets. If we do not know enough about it, we do not know how worthwhile it is.

As an investment of the taxpayers' money, I would have thought that it was a very important matter to assess how many of these young school cadets go on to a career in the defence forces. The money invested in the school cadet units could then be seen to be serving an extremely valuable purpose. I remind honourable senators that young people go into the Defence Force or into the military academies and, before long, they march out. I believe that, if people understand what the Defence Force is all about and have had a grounding in school cadets, the chances of their being equipped and trained and then marching out again will be reduced. These are all things which need to be evaluated. A cost benefit analysis needs to be carried out on school cadets. I am surprised that that does not appear to have taken place.

I draw attention to another matter relating to the report. The Committee was pleased to note, as honourable senators would notice, the considerable improvement in the program format of the explanatory notes of the Department of Defence. We understand that this has been a complex and a difficult matter for the Department and that a number of matters are still being addressed.

However, I would like to raise an item that I did ask questions about. But I am still not satisfied with the answers I have received. I refer to question Nos 76, 77 and 78 which I placed on notice. They relate to an item of $91m, provision for contingent salaries. This year, that item was placed in the Defence personnel part of the Budget Papers rather than in `Defence Other', in which it had featured in previous years. Its effect-whether that was the intention-of that change in placement was to artificially inflate the Defence personnel size of the total budget to 41.7 per cent over the previous year, whereas, without including that $91m in the Defence personnel part of the Budget, the total Defence personnel share is actually 40.6 per cent, which is the same as last year's Defence personnel total.

There is a pie chart in the Budget statements which shows that in 1989-90 there was `Defence Other' and Defence personnel, et cetera. There, Defence personnel was shown as 40.6 per cent. At that stage, there was a provision for contingent salary of $80m. In fact, that was shown in `Defence Other'. When we turn to the 1990-91 Budget statements we see that the pie chart shows that personnel has gone up to 41.7 per cent. But when we turn to page 3.62 we see that the provision for contingent salary is $91m. That has moved over into personnel and out of `Defence Other'. Why is this so? Perhaps from the answer I get to that I will able to take the matter a little further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clearer because we will spend it on personnel. I would have thought that the explanations for 76, 77 and 78 were fairly clear in what they said. SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the answers that the Minister said that I had had from the Department on question Nos 76, 77 and 78.
