SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try not to detain the Senate for too long. I think honourable senators are aware of the fact that there has been agreement that there now be a national bank inquiry, which I have been pursuing for two years. I hope to appear before that inquiry and go in with a wheelbarrow with all of the material that I have tabled in the Senate over the last two years-around about 80-odd cases out of the 350-odd that I have been pursuing-in relation to what I have referred to as malpractice and corrupt practice in banking.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I would like to chronicle briefly a particular case which I think is an outstanding one, relating to Mr and Mrs Somerset who have been in dispute with the National Australia Bank Ltd. This is a case which I will be placing before the inquiry, but I think it is essential to place it before the Senate beforehand. At the end of this brief statement I will seek to table approximately 33 attachments which substantiate the allegations which I will be placing before the Senate. I understand that that is acceptable to both the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who are on duty in the chamber and who have perused the material earlier in the day.

Mr and Mrs Somerset were successful farmers and graziers who, after 32 years in the rural industry producing wheat, sheep and cattle, sold their western rural holdings and retired to Toowoomba in Queensland. In 1952 the Somersets had commenced as soldier settlers who balloted land in the first Brigalow land development scheme in Wandoan in Queensland. In the development and growth of their rural properties and their production, the Somersets had held numerous appointments and dealings with banks, bank managers and senior bank officers, always finding them to be people of integrity on whose word and ethic they could rely as trusted officers of financial authority in the banking industry. That was their opinion of bankers.

In Toowoomba the Somersets became interested in the purchase of a property and enterprise known as Gunnadoo, was situated within the city boundary, priced at $625,000 and sited on a vantage point overlooking the city. Figures documented and produced by the vendor showed a net figure in excess of $400,000 as being certainly an appropriate valuation of the property. The Somersets frankly did not believe the valuation that was placed on the property and the vendor, Mr Cardell, in an endeavour to encourage a sale, introduced the Somersets to his bank manager, one Colin Herbert Cannon, of the National Australia Bank, 441 Ruthven Street in Toowoomba.

Mr Somerset, by appointment with Mr Cannon on 30 October and again by appointment on 1 November 1984, discussed the property and enterprise with Mr Cannon as well as the financial investment and the cash flow of the vendor Cardell before signing a contract on 2 November 1984. By appointment on 6 November, Mr and Mrs Somerset met with Mr Cannon and became customers of the National Australia Bank at the address which I have just stated in Toowoomba. The cash flow and profitability of the contracted property was the purpose of the discussion. This was Mrs Somerset's initial introduction to Mr Cannon and his bank.

Settlement of the contracted property, Gunnadoo, was to be on 16 November 1984. The Somersets informed Mr Cannon that they had previously been interested in the acquisition of a property called Glenhaven-a largely undeveloped run-down 100 acre property in close proximity to Gunnadoo. However, now with their investment in Gunnadoo they were not in a position to proceed. Cannon told the Somersets that Gunnadoo had an excellent cash flow, made enhancing statements concerning the property and paid personal tribute to Cardell, indicating in the monetary sense that Cardell's financial figures and position-as evidenced in figures from Cardell-had been derived from Gunnadoo production and profitability.

Cannon placed special emphasis on the trading record of Cardell and indicated to the Somersets that they would have no difficulty servicing a bill finance facility of $300,000. Cannon further advised the Somersets that he could facilitate in the Somerset's acquisition of Glenhaven but that the Somersets would have to transfer their business to his bank. An appointment was made for the Somersets on 8 November 1984-the day preceding the advertised National Australia Bank mortgagee sale in possession of Glenhaven by auction on 9 November 1984. By appointment on 8 November, Cannon advised the Somersets that the National Australia Bank had approved finance to the extent of $300,000 to assist in the purchasing of Glenhaven and issued the Somersets with an interim five leaf cheque book from which to operate at the auction. When the Somersets left Cannon's office on that fateful day they were completely unaware that Cannon had participated in a fraud of mammoth proportions, so great that in a few years they would be destitute: recipients of, and dependent upon, age pensions for their very survival.

Subsequent inspection of bank documents did not disclose that two contracts purchased Gunnadoo-one for $310,000 for the property and one for $315,000 for the business, including apportionment, goodwill and strawberry plants worth $250,000. Bank records indicate that the property was purchased for $625,000 in one contract.

It is now quite obvious that a conspiracy by bank personnel commenced immediately the Somersets made initial contact with the National Australia Bank and the bank gained knowledge and saw confirmation of their net worth of over $1m and their interest in property investment. The bank used them to recover large potential losses contrary to the customer's-that is, the Somerset's- interest.

At auction on 9 November 1984 the Somersets successfully bid $320,000 and contracted the property Glenhaven, sold by the National Australia Bank as the mortgagees in possession. Bank documents now reveal no prior appointments with the Manager, Mr Cannon, prior to 8 November 1984. In his position Cannon could not approve the finance in his own right. In order to issue such an approval he would have had to have the approval of his immediate superior, the Regional Manager, one Robert Arkell.

The Glenhaven contract was signed on 9 November 1984, witnessed by the National Australia Bank, and required settlement within 30 days. Settlement did not take place until 22 March 1985 due to the fact that there was an outstanding South East Queensland Electricity Board requisition order which had been in force since September 1984. This was not advertised, nor was it disclosed at the auction. Discovered documents reveal deliberate deceit by the National Australia Bank, including by administrative officers, even though they were fully aware of the existence of this major charge on the property.

When the Manager, Cannon, obtained verbal approval from his Regional Manager, Arkell, for $300,000, he was aware that this amount was completely insufficient to enable the Somersets to meet this commitment to the bank. In the period from 8 November 1984 to 1 February 1985 the Somersets had numerous interviews with Manager Cannon to complete the financial documents. However, Manager Cannon departed, purposely leaving everything in abeyance, on four weeks' annual leave.

On 13 November 1984 the Somersets transferred their banking business to the National Australia Bank at the address in Toowoomba, in accordance with Mr Cannon's statement of 6 November 1984 and the arrangements contrived by him. The relieving manager, Mr Albion, during Cannon's absence obtained his administration's approval for three loans aggregating $575,000. The loan documents were signed on 14 March 1985. By July 1985 the three loans were all in default and all repayments until this time had been made from the Somerset's personal resources.

In May 1985 Robert Cardell's son informed the Somersets that they had-to use his term-been `conned'. Official inquiries revealed Cardell's criminal record for fraud. The son revealed that Cardell's National Australia Bank overdraft had increased from $50,000 to $260,000, and after many extensions the final deadline with the bank was 31 October 1984. This was completely contrary to what Cannon had led them to believe. The Somersets instituted Supreme Court proceedings against Cardell for fraud and won the case. In the meantime, Cardell had disposed of all of his assets and the Somersets received nothing from the proceeds. Legal advice was that the Somersets should commence legal proceedings in the Federal Court against the National Australia Bank for false and misleading conduct under section 52 of the Trade Practices Act. They lost on technical grounds.

Similarly, the appeal was denied. Leave to amend the appeal pleadings to include fraud was denied because fraud had not been in the original pleading. Leave to appeal to the High Court was denied. The trial commenced without full and complete discovery from the National Australia Bank. Some duplicate documents produced as evidence at the trial were different in content to those produced in discovery which had been produced and stated in interrogatories as the original documents.

The Somersets' solicitor engaged on their behalf a former senior, now retired, National Australia Bank manager with 36 years experience in the National Australia Bank, including 16 years at managerial level. His examination of the bank records has revealed that vendor Cardell's bank account with the National Australia Bank was extremely troublesome and had a history of chronic irregularity. Cardell was unable to service his overdraft indebtedness in the prior 12 months to the contracted sale date. In fact, the overdraft had escalated from $55,000 to $240,000 in the previous three years. No other income was shown and none of this was disclosed by the bank.

To obtain formal approval for the Somersets' loan application for $300,000, manager Cannon stated to his superiors, `Cash flow confirmed at $50,000 per month is consistent with this property'. The actual monthly average confirmed by bank records was $12,936 for the previous 12 months as opposed to the $50,000 per month stated to the Somersets. Manager Cannon apparently relied on each cash flow projection which, when compared to the actual trading from bank records for the previous 12 months, amounted to 14 times the actual cash flow.

To gain approval for the Somersets' application, manager Cannon increased the market value of the National Australia Bank Gunnadoo security, dated 22 November 1984, by 82 per cent. Documents reveal that some 10 weeks earlier than 22 November 1984, manager Cannon increased the property market value by 23 per cent in the bank records. Documents further reveal that Cannon deceived his administrators by recording the property area as four hectares when the actual area was two hectares.

Before taking annual leave and leaving the loan application in abeyance, manager Cannon once again increased the market value of the bank's Gunnadoo security by $100,000 to $575,000 offering no evidence for the increase. The relieving manager, who has now had to submit a new application, was assured of the success of the application because of manager Cannon's valuation.

Manager Cannon stated in evidence that improvements by the Somersets had justified the increase. In fact, the improvements were a demountable building and the proprietorship was with the Somersets' family company over which the National Australia Bank held no security whatsoever. In fact, there were no fixed improvements to Gunnadoo which had been used by manager Cannon as the rationale for that 82 per cent increase in valuations.

In its dealings with its clients, Mr and Mrs Somerset, the National Australia Bank, through its manager Cannon, and in flagrant disregard of its fiduciary interest to its clients, deceived them as to the worth of both properties. In the case of the Gunnadoo property, the Somersets were used to rid the bank of a large potential loss and thereby protect their manager from internal disciplinary action. Similarly, in the case of the Glenhaven property the bank, as vendor, consciously concealed the requisition on the property, which in itself is a breach of its legislative duty as well as its fiduciary duty. When the Glenhaven contract was signed the bank knew that it could not settle as required by the contract. Despite its fiduciary relationship with the Somersets, the bank threatened to sue the Somersets if they tried to rescind the contract.

In both instances the bank has used its privileged position of trust to protect its own financial interests against, and to the detriment of, the interests of its customers. By its fraud, deceit and greed the National Australia Bank has reduced previously wealthy customers to penury. To add insult to injury the National Australia Bank is now attempting to force Mr and Mrs Somerset into bankruptcy. It is doing this, well aware that they have no assets left, with the sole intention of further discrediting their previously unblemished reputation and preventing any further legal action against the bank. This type of financial thuggery must be resisted by all fair minded Australians. I seek leave to table 33 documents in support of that case study.
Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 19 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister comment on forecasts by Friends of the Earth to the effect that nuclear capacity is likely to peak at 356-366Gwe globally, and 300-310Gwe for non-Comecon capacity in the year 2000, and is likely to decline rather than grow from that point on, due to the crippling costs outlined in recent UK House of Commons Reports.
(2) Are forecasts that demand for uranium will plateau at 4244000Tu/y, while prices are likely to remain depressed, accurate.

(3) What are the reasons for the discrepancy between the forecasts in (2) above, and forecasts released by the Minister's department to the Sydney Morning Herald on 9 September 1990, to the effect that demand will reach about 47 500Mtu in the same year, while current inventories are at 182 000Mtu.

(4) In view of the sale of the Government-owned stockpile of uranium for $11/lb, compared with the recent floor price of uranium of nearly $30/lb, is it unwise to bring even more uranium on to the market which would in turn lead to an even lower price.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The forecasts of Friends of the Earth (FOE) are based on several assumptions made by FOE about individual state's plans for the development of their nuclear industry and on FOE perceptions about the likely future role of nuclear power in electricity generation. Although the assumptions on which the shorter-term forecasts are based reflect generally recognised difficulties which the nuclear power industry has experienced, they would seem not to make appropriate allowance for planned growth in nuclear generating capacity later in the decade. They are, therefore, probably on the conservative side. FOE's longer-term forecasts assume, arguably somewhat prematurely, a major decline in the nuclear power industry. This does not accord with the heavy reliance several countries will continue to have on nuclear power for their energy needs. Additionally, FOE itself notes that ``major new reactor ordering round the world in the next 12-24 years would change FOE's predictions''.

(2) The uranium demand forecast mentioned is based essentially on FOE's forecasts and assumptions relating to nuclear generating capacity. In this respect alone, the demand forecasts will be conservative (see comments in (1) above). In forecasting uranium demand, many other assumptions have to be made relating, inter alia, to reactor capacity factors, fuel management techniques, enrichment tails assay, and the impact of reprocessing and use of recycled nuclear fuel. Such assumptions can vary uranium demand forecasts considerably.

(3) The figures referred to, which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 10 September, 1990, were uranium demand forecasts of the London based Uranium Institute. They are higher than FOE's for reasons associated with assumptions and forecasts made about nuclear electricity generating capacity and the technical aspects affecting demand, as outlined in (1) and (2) above.

(4) The Government-owned stockpile has not as yet been sold. Sales of Australian uranium are approved by the Government on the basis that contracts contain fair and reasonable market prices. This accords fully with the Government's uranium contract pricing policy and is in line with the Government's approach to the export of other mineral commodities over which pricing controls are exercised.
